seo.title: Online wallpaper calculator - Calculate the amount of wallpaper for a room | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online wallpaper calculator for accurately calculating the number of rolls of wallpaper to cover a room. Takes into account the dimensions of the room, windows, doors, roll sizes and margin for adjusting the pattern.

overview.title: Online wallpaper calculator
overview.content: An online wallpaper calculator will help you calculate the required number of rolls of wallpaper to cover a room. The dimensions of the room, the height of the walls, the sizes of windows and doors, the sizes of wallpaper rolls and the margin for adjusting the pattern and possible defects are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The wallpaper calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the amount of material taking into account the type of room, the method of pasting and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various types of wallpaper: vinyl, non-woven, paper, textile. Calculation formula: Number of rolls = (Wall area - Opening area) × (1 + Stock / 100) / Roll area.

calculationExamples.title: Wallpaper calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the amount of wallpaper for various rooms and types of wallpaper:

example1.title: Example 1: Bedroom 4x3 meters
example1.description: Standard bedroom with ceiling height 2.7 m, vinyl wallpaper
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window: 1.2×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Opening area: 1.2×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 3.6 m²
Usable area: 37.8 - 3.6 = 34.2 m²
Roll area: 0.53 × 10.05 = 5.33 m²
With a margin: 34.2 × 1.1 = 37.62 m²
Rolls: 37.62 / 5.33 = 7.06 ≈ 8 rolls
example1.note: Standard bedroom, it is recommended to take 8-9 rolls with a small margin

example2.title: Example 2: Living room 5x4 meters
example2.description: Large living room with a ceiling height of 2.7 m, non-woven wallpaper with a pattern
example2.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 pieces, 1.5×1.5 m each
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Stock: 15%
example2.note: For patterned wallpaper, an increased margin of 15% is recommended for adjustment

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3x2.5 meters
example3.description: Kitchen with a ceiling height of 2.5 m, moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window: 1.2×1.2 m
Door: 0.8×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Stock: 10%
example3.note: For the kitchen, moisture-resistant wallpaper that is easy to clean is recommended

example4.title: Example 4: Children's room 4x3.5 meters
example4.description: Children's room with ceiling height 2.6 m, paper wallpaper
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.6 m
Window: 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Stock: 10%
example4.note: Eco-friendly paper wallpaper is recommended for children's rooms

example5.title: Example 5: Living room with wide rolls
example5.description: Large living room 6×5 meters with a ceiling height of 3 m, wide wallpaper
example5.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 3 m
Windows: 3 pieces, 1.5×2.0 m each
Door: 1.0×2.1 m
Roll: 1.06×10.05 m
Stock: 10%
example5.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (6 + 5) × 3 = 66 m²
Opening area: 3×1.5×2.0 + 1.0×2.1 = 11.1 m²
Usable area: 66 - 11.1 = 54.9 m²
Roll area: 1.06 × 10.05 = 10.65 m²
With a margin: 54.9 × 1.1 = 60.39 m²
Rolls: 60.39 / 10.65 = 5.67 ≈ 6 rolls
example5.note: Wide rolls reduce the number of joints and simplify pasting

example6.title: Example 6: Hallway 2×1.5 meters
example6.description: Small hallway with a ceiling height of 2.5 m, washable wallpaper
example6.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (2 + 1.5) × 2.5 = 17.5 m²
Opening area: 0.9×2.0 = 1.8 m²
Usable area: 17.5 - 1.8 = 15.7 m²
Roll area: 0.53 × 10.05 = 5.33 m²
With a margin: 15.7 × 1.1 = 17.27 m²
Rolls: 17.27 / 5.33 = 3.24 ≈ 4 rolls
example6.note: Wear-resistant washable wallpaper is recommended for the hallway

calculation.title: How is the number of wallpapers calculated?
calculation.content: Calculating the amount of wallpaper includes several stages to obtain an accurate result, taking into account all the parameters of the room and the type of wallpaper.
calculation.openings: Usable area = Wall area - Window and door area
calculation.rolls: Number of rolls = Usable area × (1 + Stock / 100) / Roll area

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of wallpaper for a room?
faqItems.a: To calculate wallpaper, measure the length, width and height of the room, indicate the dimensions of all windows and doors, select the size of the wallpaper roll and the percentage of stock. The calculator will automatically calculate the required number of rolls.

faqItems.q: How many rolls of wallpaper do you need per room?
faqItems.a: The number of rolls depends on the size of the room, ceiling height, number of windows and doors. For a standard room 4x3 meters with a ceiling height of 2.7 m, you need approximately 6-8 rolls of standard size (0.53x10.05 m), taking into account a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper taking into account windows and doors?
faqItems.a: When calculating wallpaper, subtract the area of ​​all windows and doors from the total area of ​​the walls. This will allow you to obtain an accurate usable area for pasting and avoid wastage of material.

faqItems.q: How much wallpaper do you need?
faqItems.a: A margin of 10-15% for regular wallpaper and 15-20% for patterned wallpaper that requires adjustment is recommended. The reserve takes into account the fit of the pattern, defects and possible errors during pasting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a bedroom?
faqItems.a: For a bedroom, measure the dimensions of the room, indicate windows and doors. Select the type of wallpaper (vinyl, non-woven, paper). Add a margin of 10% for regular wallpaper or 15% for patterned wallpaper.

faqItems.q: What is wallpaper rapport?
faqItems.a: Wallpaper repeat is a repeating pattern on the wallpaper canvas. When calculating wallpaper with a pattern, it is necessary to take into account rapport for proper fit, which increases material consumption by 15-20%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for the living room?
faqItems.a: For the living room, measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. For a large room, it is better to use wide rolls (0.7×10.05 m or 1.06×10.05 m) to reduce the number of joints.

faqItems.q: How many meters are there in a roll of wallpaper?
faqItems.a: A standard roll of wallpaper has a size of 0.53×10.05 meters (area 5.33 m²). There are also wide rolls 0.7×10.05 m (7.04 m²) and very wide rolls 1.06×10.05 m (10.65 m²), as well as long rolls 0.53×15.0 m (7.95 m²).

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for the kitchen?
faqItems.a: For the kitchen it is recommended to use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Add a margin of 10-15% to adjust the pattern and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between vinyl and non-woven wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Vinyl wallpaper has a PVC coating, is moisture resistant and washable. Non-woven wallpaper is more durable, breathable, and better hides uneven walls. The quantity calculation for both types is the same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a bathroom?
faqItems.a: For the bathroom, use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​the door. Add a margin of 15% for higher humidity. Keep in mind that the bathroom usually has a smaller wall area.

faqItems.q: How much does wallpapering cost?
faqItems.a: The cost of wallpaper depends on the type, manufacturer and design. Paper wallpapers cost from 200 to 1000 rubles/roll, vinyl wallpapers - from 500 to 3000 rubles/roll, non-woven wallpapers - from 800 to 5000 rubles/roll. Calculate the number of rolls and multiply by the price per roll.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a children's room?
faqItems.a: For a children's room, measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. It is recommended to use eco-friendly paper wallpaper or vinyl wallpaper with a safety certificate. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: Do I need to take windows and doors into account when calculating wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Yes, be sure to take all windows and doors into account when calculating wallpaper. Subtracting the area of ​​the openings from the total area of ​​the walls allows you to obtain the exact usable area for pasting and avoid wastage of material.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper with a pattern?
faqItems.a: When calculating wallpaper with a pattern, take into account rapport - a repeating pattern. Increase the margin to 15-20% to adjust the pattern. Also consider the direction of pasting - vertical or horizontal.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a corridor?
faqItems.a: For the corridor, measure the length and width, the height of the ceilings. Consider all the doors in the hallway. It is recommended to use wear-resistant, washable wallpaper for high traffic. Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is wide wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Wide wallpapers have a width of 0.7 m or 1.06 m instead of the standard 0.53 m. They allow you to reduce the number of joints when pasting and speed up the process. The quantity is calculated using the same formula.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a balcony?
faqItems.a: For a balcony, measure the area of ​​the walls. Use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper for exterior use or insulated balconies. Consider temperature changes. Add a margin of 15% for complex shapes.

faqItems.q: How much wallpaper do you need per 1 m² of wall?
faqItems.a: The number of wallpaper rolls per 1 m² depends on the size of the roll. A standard roll of 0.53×10.05 m covers 5.33 m², which means that for 1 m² you need approximately 0.19 rolls (1 / 5.33). In practice, for 1 m² you need about 0.2 rolls, taking into account the reserve.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a studio?
faqItems.a: For a studio, measure the area of ​​all walls. Consider all windows and doors. Select the type of wallpaper depending on the zoning. For open spaces it is better to use wide rolls. Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is non-woven wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Non-woven wallpaper is made of non-woven material based on cellulose. They are durable, breathable, and hide uneven walls well. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for regular wallpaper.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a toilet?
faqItems.a: For the toilet, measure the area of ​​the walls. Subtract the area of ​​the door. Use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper. Consider the small area of ​​the room. Add a 10% margin for normal styling.

faqItems.q: What wallpaper is best for the bedroom?
faqItems.a: For the bedroom, it is recommended to use paper wallpaper (eco-friendly, breathable) or non-woven wallpaper (durable, hides unevenness). Vinyl wallpaper is suitable for damp rooms. The calculation of the quantity is the same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a living room with high ceilings?
faqItems.a: For a living room with high ceilings, measure the height of the walls from floor to ceiling. Calculate the area of ​​the walls using the standard formula. Keep in mind that high ceilings may require more material to fit the pattern. Add a margin of 15%.

faqItems.q: What is paper wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Paper wallpaper is the simplest and most environmentally friendly type of wallpaper. They are breathable, inexpensive, but less durable and moisture resistant than vinyl or non-woven fabrics. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for other types.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for an entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For an apartment, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of wallpaper for different rooms (moisture-resistant for the kitchen and bathroom, environmentally friendly for the bedroom). Add up the results for the total number of rolls.

faqItems.q: Do I need to buy wallpaper in stock?
faqItems.a: Yes, be sure to buy wallpaper with a 10-15% margin to adjust the pattern, defects and possible errors during pasting. The stock will help to avoid a situation where one roll is missing and it is difficult to find exactly the same one in the store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a hallway?
faqItems.a: For the hallway, measure the area of ​​the walls. Consider all doors. It is recommended to use wear-resistant, washable wallpaper for high traffic. Add a margin of 10-15% to adjust the pattern.

faqItems.q: What is textile wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Textile wallpaper is made of fabric (silk, linen, jute) based on paper or non-woven fabric. They are decorative, expensive, and require careful pasting. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for regular wallpaper.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for your home?
faqItems.a: For a house, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of wallpaper for different rooms. Add up the results for the total number of rolls. Keep in mind that for large rooms it is better to use wide rolls.

faqItems.q: What is the standard wallpaper width?
faqItems.a: The standard wallpaper width is 0.53 meters (53 cm). There are also wide wallpapers 0.7 m (70 cm) wide and very wide 1.06 m (106 cm). The length of a standard roll is usually 10.05 m or 15.0 m.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for a room with niches?
faqItems.a: For a room with niches, measure the total area of ​​the walls, then add the area of ​​the niches and overhangs. Consider complex shapes and angles. Add a margin of 15% for complex shapes and adjusting the pattern in the corners.

faqItems.q: What is washable wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Washable wallpaper is wallpaper with a protective coating that can be washed with a damp cloth. Usually this is vinyl or non-woven wallpaper with a special coating. They are suitable for kitchens, hallways and other rooms with high levels of dirt.

overview.title: Paint calculator
overview.content: An online paint calculator will help you calculate the required amount of paint for painting walls. The dimensions of the room, the number of layers, the consumption rate and the reserve for losses are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The paint calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the amount of material based on surface type, application method and operating conditions. Suitable for calculating various types of paints: water-based, oil-based, acrylic, latex. Calculation formula: Total amount of paint = (Area of ​​walls - Area of ​​doors and windows) × Consumption rate (l/m²) × Number of layers × (1 + Stock / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Paint calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the amount of paint for various rooms and types of paint:

example1.title: Example 1: Room 3x4 meters
example1.description: Standard room with ceiling height 2.7 m, water-based paint
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window and door area: 4.5 m²
Number of layers: 2
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Usable area: 37.8 - 4.5 = 33.3 m²
Consumption per layer: 33.3 × 0.12 = 4.0 l
Total consumption: 4.0 × 2 × 1.1 = 8.8 l
example1.result: Required: 8.8 l (4 cans of 2.5 l each)
example1.note: Standard room for painting, it is recommended to take 4-5 cans with a small margin

example2.title: Example 2: Large living room
example2.description: Spacious living room with large windows, acrylic paint
example2.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 3 m
Window and door area: 12 m²
Number of layers: 2
Consumption rate: 0.15 l/m²
Stock: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (6 + 5) × 3 = 66 m²
Usable area: 66 - 12 = 54 m²
Consumption per layer: 54 × 0.15 = 8.1 l
Total consumption: 8.1 × 2 × 1.15 = 18.6 l
example2.result: Required: 18.6 l (8 cans of 2.5 l each)
example2.note: For large rooms it is recommended to increase the margin to 15%

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen with tiles
example3.description: Kitchen where part of the walls is covered with tiles, only the upper part needs to be painted
example3.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Area under tiles: 15 m²
Window and door area: 3 m²
Number of layers: 2
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Area to be painted: 37.8 - 15 - 3 = 19.8 m²
Consumption per layer: 19.8 × 0.12 = 2.4 l
Total consumption: 2.4 × 2 × 1.1 = 5.3 l
example3.result: Required: 5.3 l (3 cans of 2 l each)
example3.note: It is better to choose washable paint for the kitchen

example4.title: Example 4: Bedroom, single layer
example4.description: Bedroom with good surface preparation, finishing coat
example4.input:
Length: 4.5 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window and door area: 5 m²
Number of layers: 1
Consumption rate: 0.1 l/m²
Stock: 5%
example4.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4.5 + 3.5) × 2.5 = 40 m²
Usable area: 40 - 5 = 35 m²
Consumption per layer: 35 × 0.1 = 3.5 l
Total consumption: 3.5 × 1 × 1.05 = 3.7 l
example4.result: Required: 3.7 l (2 cans of 2 l each)
example4.note: For the finishing layer the consumption is usually less

example5.title: Example 5: Children's room
example5.description: Children's room requiring high-quality coating
example5.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window and door area: 6 m²
Number of layers: 3
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 15%
example5.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3.5) × 2.7 = 40.5 m²
Usable area: 40.5 - 6 = 34.5 m²
Consumption per layer: 34.5 × 0.12 = 4.1 l
Total consumption: 4.1 × 3 × 1.15 = 14.1 l
example5.result: Required: 14.1 l (6 cans of 2.5 l each)
example5.note: For children's rooms, it is recommended to use safe paints and increase the number of layers.

example6.title: Example 6: Corridor
example6.description: Narrow corridor with minimal windows
example6.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 1.2 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door area: 2 m²
Number of layers: 2
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (6 + 1.2) × 2.5 = 36 m²
Usable area: 36 - 2 = 34 m²
Consumption per layer: 34 × 0.12 = 4.1 l
Total consumption: 4.1 × 2 × 1.1 = 9.0 l
example6.result: Required: 9.0 l (4 cans of 2.5 l each)
example6.note: For corridors it is better to choose paints with increased wear resistance

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of paint?
faqItems.a: To calculate paint, use the formula: (Area of ​​walls - Area of ​​windows and doors) × Consumption rate (l/m²) × Number of layers × (1 + Stock / 100). The consumption rate is usually 0.1-0.15 l/m².

faqItems.q: What is the paint consumption per 1 m²?
faqItems.a: Paint consumption is usually 0.1-0.15 l/m² for one layer. For water-based paint, the consumption may be lower, for oil-based paint it may be higher.

faqItems.q: How many layers of paint are needed?
faqItems.a: Usually 2 layers of paint are enough for a high-quality coating. Dark colors may require more layers on top of light colors.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ceiling paint?
faqItems.a: To calculate ceiling paint, use the ceiling area (length x width) instead of the wall area. Formula: Ceiling area × Consumption rate × Number of layers × (1 + Reserve / 100). The ceiling usually requires 2 coats of paint.

faqItems.q: How much paint should I take?
faqItems.a: It is recommended to take a reserve of 10-15% of the calculated amount of paint. This compensates for losses during application, cutting and possible errors in calculations. For large rooms, the reserve can be increased to 15-20%.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between water-based and acrylic paint?
faqItems.a: Water-based paint is the general name for water-based paints, including acrylic. Acrylic paint has acrylic binders and is more durable. For calculations, use the same consumption rate of 0.1-0.15 l/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for a facade?
faqItems.a: The calculation of paint for the facade is similar to interior work, but the consumption rate may be higher (0.15-0.2 l/m²) due to the unevenness of the surface. Consider the area of ​​all walls of the building and subtract windows and doors.

faqItems.q: How much does it cost to paint a room?
faqItems.a: The cost of painting depends on the type of paint (from 200 to 2000 rubles per liter), the area of ​​the room and the number of layers. Use a calculator to determine how much paint you need, then multiply by the price per liter.

faqItems.q: Which paint to choose for the kitchen?
faqItems.a: For the kitchen, choose washable paint with a high resistance to moisture and grease. The consumption of such paints is usually standard - 0.12-0.15 l/m². 2 layers are recommended for protection.

faqItems.q: Do I need to prime the walls before painting?
faqItems.a: Primer is required for new walls and recommended for old ones. The primer reduces paint consumption by 10-20% and improves adhesion. Paint calculation does not include primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for an irregularly shaped room?
faqItems.a: For an irregularly shaped room, measure each wall separately, then add up the areas. Formula: Area = (Wall1 + Wall2 + Wall3 + Wall4) - Area of ​​windows and doors. Use this area in the calculator.

faqItems.q: What is the paint consumption for a bathroom?
faqItems.a: For the bathroom, use moisture-resistant paint with a consumption of 0.12-0.15 l/m². 2-3 layers are recommended to protect against moisture. Take into account the small room and possible uneven walls.

faqItems.q: How long does it take for paint to dry between coats?
faqItems.a: Water-based paint dries in 2-4 hours at room temperature. Acrylic paint dries in 4-6 hours. Oil paint dries in 24-48 hours. Consider drying time when planning your work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for a room with arches?
faqItems.a: For a room with arches, measure the area of ​​the arches separately as part of the walls or subtract from the total area. Arches usually occupy a small area and do not greatly affect the calculation. Use the standard formula.

faqItems.q: Does paint color affect consumption?
faqItems.a: Dark paints may require 3 coats instead of 2 to evenly cover a light surface. Light colors can be covered well in 2 coats. Take this into account when calculating, increasing the number of layers for dark colors.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for wooden walls?
faqItems.a: For wooden walls, the consumption rate is higher due to absorbency - 0.15-0.2 l/m². Pre-priming is recommended. Typically 2-3 coats of paint are required for good coverage.

faqItems.q: Which tool affects paint consumption?
faqItems.a: A brush consumes 10-15% more paint than a roller. The spray gun is the most economical - 5-10% less consumption. For calculations, use the average consumption rate taking into account the tool.

faqItems.q: Can I use old paint?
faqItems.a: Old paint can be used if it has not thickened or changed color. Check consistency and stir before use. The consumption of old paint may be slightly higher.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for drywall?
faqItems.a: For drywall, the standard consumption rate is 0.12 l/m², but preliminary priming is required. Usually 2 layers of paint are enough. Consider the area of ​​all sheets of drywall.

faqItems.q: How much paint does one room need?
faqItems.a: For a standard 3x4 m room with a ceiling height of 2.7 m, about 8-10 liters of paint per 2 layers are required. An accurate calculation can be obtained using a calculator with the parameters of your room.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint taking into account doors?
faqItems.a: The door area is subtracted from the total wall area before calculation. Measure the width and height of each door, multiply and subtract from the wall area. A standard door occupies 1.8-2 m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for a balcony?
faqItems.a: For a balcony, measure the area of ​​all walls and ceiling if it will be painted. The standard consumption rate is 0.12 l/m². Keep in mind that for a balcony it is better to use façade paint that is resistant to temperature changes.

faqItems.q: What is paint hiding power?
faqItems.a: Hiding power is the ability of paint to cover the color of a surface. High hiding power means less consumption. The hiding power is indicated on the paint can and affects the application rate. The higher the hiding power, the lower the consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for a ceiling with texture?
faqItems.a: For a ceiling with texture, the consumption rate is 20-30% higher due to the increased surface area. Use a flow rate of 0.15-0.18 l/m² instead of the standard one. A textured surface requires more paint.

faqItems.q: Do I need to dilute the paint with water?
faqItems.a: Water-based paint can be diluted with water up to 5-10% for ease of application. Thinning slightly increases consumption, but improves spreadability. When calculating, take into account the standard consumption rate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for a room with columns?
faqItems.a: For a room with columns, measure the area of ​​the columns as part of the walls (perimeter x height) and add to the total area of ​​the walls. Columns require a standard paint consumption rate of 0.12 l/m².

faqItems.q: How much paint does it take to paint 3 meter high walls?
faqItems.a: The height of the walls affects the area, but not the flow rate. For a 4 x 3 m room with a height of 3 m, wall area = 2 × (4 + 3) × 3 = 42 m². At a consumption rate of 0.12 l/m² and 2 layers you need: 42 × 0.12 × 2 × 1.1 = 11.1 l.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for a room with a bay window?
faqItems.a: For a room with a bay window, measure the area of ​​all walls, including the bay window walls. A bay window adds additional wall space. Use the calculator with the total area of ​​all surfaces to be painted.

faqItems.q: Does temperature affect paint consumption?
faqItems.a: Air temperature affects drying time, but only slightly on consumption. At high temperatures, paint dries faster and may require an additional coat. At low temperatures, consumption may increase slightly.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for a room with niches?
faqItems.a: For a room with niches, measure the area of ​​the niche walls and add to the total area. Niches increase the area for painting. Use the standard application rate of 0.12 l/m² for all surfaces.

faqItems.q: How much paint does it take to paint the entire apartment?
faqItems.a: To paint the entire apartment, calculate each room separately and add up the results. An average three-room apartment requires 40-60 liters of paint on all walls, depending on the size of the rooms.

seo.title: Tile adhesive calculator online - Tile adhesive calculation | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online tile adhesive calculator for accurately calculating the amount of adhesive for laying ceramic tiles, porcelain tiles and mosaics. Takes into account the floor area, tile size, joint width, consumption rate and reserve.

overview.title: Tile adhesive calculator online
overview.content: An online tile adhesive calculator will help you calculate the required amount of adhesive for laying ceramic tiles, porcelain tiles, mosaics on the floor and walls. The floor area, tile size, joint width, consumption rate and margin for losses and adjustment are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The tile adhesive calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the amount of material based on the type of adhesive, tile size, installation method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various types of adhesives: cement, dispersion, epoxy, polyurethane. Calculation formula: Amount of glue = (Floor area - Area of ​​openings) × Consumption rate (kg/m²) × (1 + Stock / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Examples of tile adhesive calculations
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the amount of tile adhesive for various rooms and types of tiles:

example1.title: Example 1: Bathroom 3x2 meters
example1.description: Standard bathroom with ceramic tiles 30x30 cm
example1.input:
Floor area: 6 m²
Opening area: 0.5 m²
Tile size: 0.09 m² (30×30 cm)
Seam width: 2 mm
Consumption rate: 4 kg/m²
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Usable area: 6 - 0.5 = 5.5 m²
Glue consumption: 5.5 × 4 = 22 kg
With reserve: 22 × 1.1 = 24.2 kg
Packages (25 kg): 24.2 / 25 = 0.97 ≈ 1 package
example1.note: Standard bathroom, it is recommended to take 1-2 packages with a small margin

example2.title: Example 2: Kitchen 4x3 meters
example2.description: Kitchen with porcelain stoneware 60×60 cm
example2.input:
Floor area: 12 m²
Opening area: 1.2 m²
Tile size: 0.36 m² (60×60 cm)
Seam width: 3 mm
Consumption rate: 5 kg/m²
Stock: 15%
example2.calculation:
Usable area: 12 - 1.2 = 10.8 m²
Glue consumption: 10.8 × 5 = 54 kg
With reserve: 54 × 1.15 = 62.1 kg
Packs (25 kg): 62.1 / 25 = 2.48 ≈ 3 packs
example2.note: For large-format tiles, an increased margin of 15% is recommended.

example3.title: Example 3: Hallway 2×1.5 meters
example3.description: Small hallway with ceramic tiles 20×20 cm
example3.input:
Floor area: 3 m²
Opening area: 0.3 m²
Tile size: 0.04 m² (20×20 cm)
Seam width: 2 mm
Consumption rate: 3.5 kg/m²
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Usable area: 3 - 0.3 = 2.7 m²
Glue consumption: 2.7 × 3.5 = 9.45 kg
With reserve: 9.45 × 1.1 = 10.4 kg
Packages (25 kg): 10.4 / 25 = 0.42 ≈ 1 package
example3.note: For small tiles, glue consumption is less

example4.title: Example 4: Bathroom with mosaic tiles
example4.description: Bathroom 2.5x2 meters with mosaic 10x10 cm
example4.input:
Floor area: 5 m²
Opening area: 0.5 m²
Tile size: 0.01 m² (10×10 cm)
Seam width: 2 mm
Consumption rate: 6 kg/m²
Stock: 15%
example4.calculation:
Usable area: 5 - 0.5 = 4.5 m²
Glue consumption: 4.5 × 6 = 27 kg
With reserve: 27 × 1.15 = 31.05 kg
Packs (25 kg): 31.05 / 25 = 1.24 ≈ 2 packs
example4.note: For mosaics, glue consumption is higher due to the large number of seams

example5.title: Example 5: Living room with large tiles
example5.description: Living room 6x5 meters with porcelain tiles 120x60 cm
example5.input:
Floor area: 30 m²
Opening area: 2.5 m²
Tile size: 0.72 m² (120×60 cm)
Seam width: 3 mm
Consumption rate: 6 kg/m²
Stock: 15%
example5.calculation:
Usable area: 30 - 2.5 = 27.5 m²
Glue consumption: 27.5 × 6 = 165 kg
With reserve: 165 × 1.15 = 189.75 kg
Packs (25 kg): 189.75 / 25 = 7.59 ≈ 8 packs
example5.note: Very large tiles require special adhesive and increased consumption

example6.title: Example 6: Balcony 1.5×1 meter
example6.description: Insulated balcony with ceramic tiles 30×30 cm
example6.input:
Floor area: 1.5 m²
Opening area: 0 m²
Tile size: 0.09 m² (30×30 cm)
Seam width: 2 mm
Consumption rate: 4 kg/m²
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Usable area: 1.5 - 0 = 1.5 m²
Glue consumption: 1.5 × 4 = 6 kg
With reserve: 6 × 1.1 = 6.6 kg
Packages (25 kg): 6.6 / 25 = 0.26 ≈ 1 package
example6.note: For the balcony it is recommended to use frost-resistant glue

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of tile adhesive?
faqItems.a: To calculate tile adhesive, measure the floor area, subtract the area of ​​the openings, multiply by the consumption rate (usually 3-6 kg/m²) and add a margin of 10-15%. The calculator will automatically perform all calculations.

faqItems.q: How much glue is needed for 1 m² of tiles?
faqItems.a: The consumption of tile adhesive is usually 3-5 kg/m² for standard tiles measuring 30×30 cm. For large-format tiles (60×60 cm and larger) the consumption can be 5-7 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate mosaic glue?
faqItems.a: For mosaics, glue consumption is higher due to the large number of seams. It is recommended to use a consumption rate of 5-7 kg/m² and increase the margin to 15-20% for adjustment.

faqItems.q: What adhesive is best for porcelain tiles?
faqItems.a: For porcelain tiles, it is recommended to use reinforced cement adhesive or dispersion adhesive with increased adhesion. Consumption is 5-6 kg/m² for tiles measuring 60x60 cm.

faqItems.q: Do I need to take the width of the seam into account when calculating the adhesive?
faqItems.a: Yes, the width of the seam affects the glue consumption. The wider the seam, the greater the glue consumption. For a seam of 2-3 mm, the consumption is standard; for a seam of 5 mm or more, the consumption increases by 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for a bathroom?
faqItems.a: For the bathroom, use moisture-resistant dispersion adhesive. Measure the floor area, subtract the area of ​​the openings. For standard 30x30 cm tiles, use a consumption rate of 4-5 kg/m² with a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much does a package of tile adhesive weigh?
faqItems.a: A standard package of tile adhesive weighs 25 kg. There are also packages of 5 kg, 10 kg and 50 kg. For large volumes, it is more convenient to buy packages of 25 or 50 kg.

faqItems.q: How to calculate floor adhesive?
faqItems.a: For flooring, measure the area in square meters. Keep in mind that floors usually require more adhesive due to the higher load. Use a consumption rate of 4-6 kg/m² depending on the size of the tiles.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls, the calculation is similar to that for the floor. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. For walls, you can use a slightly lower consumption rate of 3-4 kg/m² for standard tiles.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between cement and dispersion adhesive?
faqItems.a: Cement adhesive is universal, suitable for dry rooms. Dispersion adhesive is moisture-resistant, suitable for bathrooms and kitchens. Consumption for both types is approximately the same - 3-5 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate glue for the kitchen?
faqItems.a: For the kitchen, use moisture-resistant dispersion adhesive or reinforced cement adhesive. Measure the floor area, subtract the area of ​​the openings. For standard tiles, use a consumption rate of 4-5 kg/m² with a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much adhesive is needed for 60x60 cm tiles?
faqItems.a: For 60x60 cm tiles, the adhesive consumption is usually 5-6 kg/m². This is due to the large size of the tiles and the need for a thicker layer of adhesive for reliable fixation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate glue for a hallway?
faqItems.a: For the hallway, measure the floor area. Take into account high traffic, use wear-resistant glue. For standard tiles, use a consumption rate of 4-5 kg/m² with a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: Do I need to buy extra glue?
faqItems.a: Yes, be sure to buy glue with a margin of 10-15% for adjustment, defects and possible errors during installation. The stock will help to avoid a situation where one bag is missing and it is difficult to find exactly the same one in the store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for ceramic tiles?
faqItems.a: For standard size ceramic tiles (30x30 cm), use a consumption rate of 3-4 kg/m². Measure the floor area, subtract the area of ​​the openings, multiply by the consumption rate and add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is epoxy tile adhesive?
faqItems.a: Epoxy adhesive is a two-component adhesive for difficult operating conditions. It is very durable, moisture resistant, but expensive. Consumption is 5-7 kg/m². Used for industrial premises and difficult conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate toilet glue?
faqItems.a: For the toilet, measure the floor area. Use moisture-resistant dispersion adhesive. Consider the small area of ​​the room. For standard tiles, use a consumption rate of 4 kg/m² with a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: How much does tile adhesive cost?
faqItems.a: The cost of tile adhesive depends on the type, manufacturer and quality. Cement adhesive costs from 150 to 500 rubles/bag (25 kg), dispersion adhesive - from 300 to 800 rubles/bag, epoxy - from 1000 to 3000 rubles/bag.

faqItems.q: How to calculate glue for a balcony?
faqItems.a: For balconies, use frost-resistant glue for exterior work or insulated balconies. Measure the floor area. Consider temperature changes. Use a consumption rate of 4-5 kg/m² with a margin of 15% for difficult conditions.

faqItems.q: What is the consumption of adhesive for wall tiles?
faqItems.a: For walls, the adhesive consumption is usually slightly less than for the floor - 3-4 kg/m² for standard 30x30 cm tiles. This is due to the fact that on the walls the load is less and a thinner layer of adhesive can be used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for large tiles?
faqItems.a: For large tiles (60×60 cm and more), the adhesive consumption increases to 5-7 kg/m². This is due to the need for a thicker layer of adhesive to securely fix large tiles. Add a margin of 15%.

faqItems.q: What is polyurethane tile adhesive?
faqItems.a: Polyurethane adhesive is a flexible one-component adhesive for large tiles and difficult conditions. It is very elastic and moisture resistant. Consumption is 3-4 kg/m². More expensive than cement glue.

faqItems.q: How to calculate glue for an entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For an apartment, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of glue for different rooms (moisture-resistant for the bathroom and kitchen, regular for living rooms). Add up the results for the total number of packages.

faqItems.q: Do I need to take into account the size of the tiles when calculating the adhesive?
faqItems.a: Yes, the size of the tile directly affects the adhesive consumption. The larger the tile, the greater the glue consumption. For small tiles (up to 20×20 cm) consumption is 3-4 kg/m², for medium (30×30 cm) - 4-5 kg/m², for large (60×60 cm and more) - 5-7 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate glue for complex shapes?
faqItems.a: For complex shapes (niches, protrusions, corners), add a margin of 15-20% to the usual calculation. Consider the need to adjust the tiles and the additional cost of adhesive in hard-to-reach places.

faqItems.q: How much adhesive is needed for 120x60 cm tiles?
faqItems.a: For very large tiles 120x60 cm, the adhesive consumption is 6-7 kg/m². This is due to the large size of the tiles and the need for a thick layer of adhesive for reliable fixation. Use special adhesive for large format tiles.

faqItems.q: How to calculate glue for home?
faqItems.a: For a house, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of glue for different spaces. Add up the results for the total number of packages. Keep in mind that for large rooms it is better to buy glue in bulk.

faqItems.q: What is white tile adhesive?
faqItems.a: White tile adhesive is used on light-colored tiles and mosaics to prevent dark adhesive from showing through the tiles. Consumption is the same as for conventional glue - 3-5 kg/m². Costs more than regular glue.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for underfloor heating?
faqItems.a: For heated floors, use a special elastic adhesive that can withstand temperature changes. Consumption is 4-6 kg/m². Add a margin of 15% to account for thermal expansion.

faqItems.q: How long does it take for tile adhesive to dry?
faqItems.a: The drying time of tile adhesive depends on the type. Cement adhesive dries in 24-48 hours, dispersion adhesive - 12-24 hours, epoxy adhesive - 6-12 hours. Consider drying time when planning your work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for exterior use?
faqItems.a: For exterior use, use frost-resistant adhesive for exterior use. Measure the surface area. Use a consumption rate of 4-6 kg/m² with a margin of 20% to take into account changes in temperature and humidity.

faqItems.q: What is reinforced tile adhesive?
faqItems.a: Reinforced tile adhesive has increased strength and adhesion. Used for large format tiles and difficult conditions. Consumption is 5-6 kg/m². Costs more than regular glue.

faqItems.q: How to calculate glue for repair?
faqItems.a: To make repairs, measure the area of ​​the floor or wall that needs to be replastered. Use the application rate depending on the size of the tile. Add a margin of 10-15% for adjustment and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What is the adhesive consumption rate for 30x30 cm tiles?
faqItems.a: For standard 30x30 cm tiles, the adhesive consumption rate is 3-4 kg/m². This is the average consumption for most types of cement and dispersion adhesives when installed correctly.

seo.title: Calculator spats online - Recording of the spats for wall | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online putty calculator for accurately calculating the amount of putty for leveling walls before painting or wallpapering. Takes into account the size of the room, the number of layers, consumption rate and reserve.

overview.title: Online putty calculator
overview.content: An online putty calculator will help you calculate the required amount of putty to level the walls before painting or wallpapering. The dimensions of the room, the height of the walls, the area of ​​windows and doors, the number of layers, the consumption rate and the margin for losses and adjustment are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The putty calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the amount of material based on the type of putty, surface condition, application method and operating conditions. Suitable for calculating various types of putty: starting, finishing, universal, gypsum, cement. Calculation formula: Amount of putty = (Wall area - Opening area) × Consumption rate (kg/m²) × Number of layers × (1 + Stock / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Examples of putty calculations
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the amount of putty for various rooms and types of putty:

example1.title: Example 1: Bedroom 4x3 meters
example1.description: Standard bedroom with ceiling height 2.7 m, starting and finishing putty
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window: 1.2×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption rate: 1.2 kg/m²
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Opening area: 1.2×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 3.6 m²
Usable area: 37.8 - 3.6 = 34.2 m²
Consumption per layer: 34.2 × 1.2 = 41.04 kg
Consumption per 2 layers: 41.04 × 2 = 82.08 kg
With reserve: 82.08 × 1.1 = 90.29 kg
Packages (25 kg): 90.29 / 25 = 3.61 ≈ 4 packages
example1.note: Standard bedroom, it is recommended to take 4-5 packs with a small margin

example2.title: Example 2: Living room 5x4 meters
example2.description: Large living room with ceiling height 2.7 m, universal putty
example2.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 pieces, 1.5×1.5 m each
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption rate: 1.3 kg/m²
Stock: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (5 + 4) × 2.7 = 48.6 m²
Opening area: 2×1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 6.3 m²
Usable area: 48.6 - 6.3 = 42.3 m²
Consumption per layer: 42.3 × 1.3 = 54.99 kg
Consumption per 2 layers: 54.99 × 2 = 109.98 kg
With reserve: 109.98 × 1.15 = 126.48 kg
Packs (25 kg): 126.48 / 25 = 5.06 ≈ 6 packs
example2.note: For a large room, an increased margin of 15% is recommended.

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3x2.5 meters
example3.description: Kitchen with a ceiling height of 2.5 m, cement putty for wet rooms
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window: 1.2×1.2 m
Door: 0.8×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption rate: 1.4 kg/m²
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (3 + 2.5) × 2.5 = 27.5 m²
Opening area: 1.2×1.2 + 0.8×2.0 = 3.04 m²
Usable area: 27.5 - 3.04 = 24.46 m²
Consumption per layer: 24.46 × 1.4 = 34.24 kg
Consumption per 2 layers: 34.24 × 2 = 68.48 kg
With reserve: 68.48 × 1.1 = 75.33 kg
Packages (25 kg): 75.33 / 25 = 3.01 ≈ 4 packages
example3.note: We recommend moisture-resistant cement putty for the kitchen.

example4.title: Example 4: Children's room 4x3.5 meters
example4.description: Children's room with ceiling height 2.6 m, gypsum putty
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.6 m
Window: 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption rate: 1.2 kg/m²
Stock: 10%
example4.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3.5) × 2.6 = 39.0 m²
Opening area: 1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 4.05 m²
Usable area: 39.0 - 4.05 = 34.95 m²
Consumption per layer: 34.95 × 1.2 = 41.94 kg
Consumption per 2 layers: 41.94 × 2 = 83.88 kg
With reserve: 83.88 × 1.1 = 92.27 kg
Packages (25 kg): 92.27 / 25 = 3.69 ≈ 4 packs
example4.note: Eco-friendly gypsum putty is recommended for children's rooms.

example5.title: Example 5: Ceiling 6x5 meters
example5.description: Large ceiling with severe unevenness, starting and finishing putty
example5.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m
Ceiling area: 30 m²
Layers: 3
Consumption rate: 1.5 kg/m²
Stock: 15%
example5.calculation:
Usable area: 30 m²
Consumption per layer: 30 × 1.5 = 45 kg
Consumption per 3 layers: 45 × 3 = 135 kg
With reserve: 135 × 1.15 = 155.25 kg
Packs (25 kg): 155.25 / 25 = 6.21 ≈ 7 packs
example5.note: Severely uneven ceilings require more layers and increased consumption.

example6.title: Example 6: Bathroom 2x1.5 meters
example6.description: Small bathroom with a ceiling height of 2.5 m, moisture-resistant putty
example6.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption rate: 1.3 kg/m²
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (2 + 1.5) × 2.5 = 17.5 m²
Opening area: 0.9×2.0 = 1.8 m²
Usable area: 17.5 - 1.8 = 15.7 m²
Consumption per layer: 15.7 × 1.3 = 20.41 kg
Consumption per 2 layers: 20.41 × 2 = 40.82 kg
With reserve: 40.82 × 1.1 = 44.9 kg
Packages (25 kg): 44.9 / 25 = 1.8 ≈ 2 packages
example6.note: Bathroom requires moisture-resistant putty

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of putty?
faqItems.a: To calculate the putty, measure the length, width and height of the walls of the room, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors, multiply by the consumption rate (usually 1-1.5 kg/m²), multiply by the number of layers and add a margin of 10-15%. The calculator will automatically perform all calculations.

faqItems.q: How much putty is needed per 1 m²?
faqItems.a: Putty consumption is usually 1-1.5 kg/m² for starting putty and 0.8-1.2 kg/m² for finishing putty per layer. For very uneven surfaces, the consumption may be higher.

faqItems.q: How many layers of putty are needed?
faqItems.a: Usually 2 layers are enough: one layer of starting putty and one layer of finishing putty. For very uneven walls, 3-4 layers of starting putty plus a finishing coat may be required.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between starting and finishing putty?
faqItems.a: Starting putty is used to level out significant unevenness (consumption 1.2-1.5 kg/m²). Finishing putty is used for final leveling (consumption 0.8-1.2 kg/m²). Universal putty can be used for both starting and finishing.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a bedroom?
faqItems.a: For a bedroom, measure the dimensions of the room, indicate the area of ​​windows and doors. Usually 2 layers are enough (starting + finishing). Use a rate of 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a ceiling?
faqItems.a: For the ceiling, measure the ceiling area in square meters. Ceilings usually require more putty due to the difficulty of application. Use a consumption rate of 1.2-1.5 kg/m² per layer. Add a margin of 15%.

faqItems.q: Which putty is best for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls, it is recommended to use gypsum or universal putty for dry rooms. For wet rooms (kitchen, bathroom), use cement or polymer moisture-resistant putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for the kitchen?
faqItems.a: For the kitchen, use moisture-resistant cement or polymer putty. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Use a consumption rate of 1.3-1.5 kg/m² per layer for wet areas. Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much does a pack of putty weigh?
faqItems.a: A standard package of putty weighs 25 kg. There are also packages of 5 kg, 10 kg and 50 kg. For large volumes, it is more convenient to buy packages of 25 or 50 kg.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a bathroom?
faqItems.a: For the bathroom, use moisture-resistant cement or polymer putty. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​the door. Use a consumption rate of 1.3-1.5 kg/m² per layer. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between gypsum and cement putty?
faqItems.a: Gypsum putty is suitable for dry rooms, easy to sand, consumption 1-1.3 kg/m². Cement putty is moisture-resistant, suitable for wet rooms, consumption 1.3-1.5 kg/m². The quantity calculation for both types is the same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for the living room?
faqItems.a: For the living room, measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Usually 2 layers are enough (starting + finishing). Use a rate of 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: Do I need to take windows and doors into account when calculating putty?
faqItems.a: Yes, be sure to take all windows and doors into account when calculating the putty. Subtracting the area of ​​the openings from the total area of ​​the walls allows you to obtain the exact usable area for processing and avoid wastage of material.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a children's room?
faqItems.a: For a children's room, measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. It is recommended to use environmentally friendly gypsum putty. Use a rate of 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: What is universal putty?
faqItems.a: Universal putty can be used for both the starting and finishing layers. It is convenient for small jobs. Consumption is 1-1.3 kg/m² per layer. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for conventional putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a corridor?
faqItems.a: For the corridor, measure the length and width, the height of the ceilings. Consider all the doors in the hallway. Use a rate of 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add 10-15% margin for adjustment.

faqItems.q: How much putty is needed for a 20 m² room?
faqItems.a: For a room with an area of ​​20 m² (approximately 4x5 m) with a standard ceiling height of 2.7 m, you need approximately 50-70 kg of putty (2-3 packages of 25 kg each) for 2 layers, taking into account a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a studio?
faqItems.a: For a studio, measure the area of ​​all walls. Consider all windows and doors. Select the type of putty depending on the zoning. For open spaces, use an all-purpose putty. Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is polymer putty?
faqItems.a: Polymer putty is a modern type of putty based on polymers. It is elastic, moisture resistant, and easy to apply. Consumption is 1-1.3 kg/m² per layer. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for conventional putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a toilet?
faqItems.a: For the toilet, measure the area of ​​the walls. Subtract the area of ​​the door. Use moisture-resistant cement or polymer putty. Consider the small area of ​​the room. Use a rate of 1.3 kg/m² per layer. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: Which putty is best for painting?
faqItems.a: For painting, it is recommended to use finishing gypsum or universal putty. It creates a smooth surface, consumption 0.8-1.2 kg/m² per layer. After puttying, be sure to prime the surface before painting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for an entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For an apartment, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of putty for different rooms (moisture-resistant for the kitchen and bathroom, gypsum for living rooms). Add up the results for the total number of packages.

faqItems.q: Do I need to buy extra putty?
faqItems.a: Yes, be sure to buy putty with a 10-15% margin for adjustment, defects and possible errors during application. The stock will help to avoid a situation where one package is missing and it is difficult to find exactly the same one in the store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a hallway?
faqItems.a: For the hallway, measure the area of ​​the walls. Consider all doors. Use a wear-resistant putty for high traffic. Use a rate of 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add 10-15% margin for adjustment.

faqItems.q: What is latex putty?
faqItems.a: Latex putty is an elastic polymer putty with the addition of latex. It is very elastic, moisture resistant, and easy to apply. Consumption is 1-1.2 kg/m² per layer. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for conventional putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a home?
faqItems.a: For a house, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of putty for different rooms. Add up the results for the total number of packages. Keep in mind that for large rooms it is better to buy putty in bulk.

faqItems.q: How long does it take for putty to dry?
faqItems.a: The drying time of the putty depends on the type and thickness of the layer. Gypsum putty dries in 24-48 hours, cement putty - 48-72 hours, polymer putty - 12-24 hours. Consider drying time when planning your work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for very uneven walls?
faqItems.a: For very uneven walls, increase the number of layers to 3-4, use an increased consumption rate of 1.5-1.8 kg/m² per layer, add a margin of 15-20% to the usual calculation. Consider the need to level out significant unevenness.

faqItems.q: What is acrylic putty?
faqItems.a: Acrylic putty is a universal polymer putty based on acrylic. It is elastic, moisture resistant, suitable for various surfaces. Consumption is 1-1.3 kg/m² per layer. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for conventional putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for repair?
faqItems.a: To repair, measure the area of ​​the walls or ceiling that needs to be replastered. Use the application rate depending on the type of putty. Add a margin of 10-15% for adjustment and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What is the consumption rate of putty for the starting layer?
faqItems.a: For the starting layer, the putty consumption rate is 1.2-1.5 kg/m², depending on the unevenness of the surface. For very uneven surfaces, consumption may be higher - up to 1.8 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for wallpaper?
faqItems.a: To prepare walls for wallpaper, use starting and finishing putty. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Use a rate of 1.2 kg/m² per coat for 2 coats. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: What is finishing putty?
faqItems.a: Finishing putty is used for final leveling of the surface before painting or wallpapering. It creates a smooth surface, consumption is 0.8-1.2 kg/m² per layer. Apply over starting putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for a ceiling with a suspended structure?
faqItems.a: For a suspended ceiling, calculate the ceiling area. Use a consumption rate of 1.2-1.5 kg/m² per layer. Add 15% margin for complex shapes and fits. Consider the need to level the base ceiling before installing the suspended structure.

seo.title: Primer calculator online - Calculation of primer for walls | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online primer calculator for accurately calculating the amount of primer to prepare the surface of walls before painting or wallpapering. Takes into account the size of the room, consumption rate and reserve.

overview.title: Primer calculator online
overview.content: An online primer calculator will help you calculate the required amount of primer to prepare the surface of the walls before painting or wallpapering. The dimensions of the room, the height of the walls, the area of ​​windows and doors, the consumption rate and the reserve for losses are taken into account. The primer is applied in one layer.
overview.additionalContent: The primer calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the amount of material based on primer type, surface condition, application method and operating conditions. Suitable for calculating various types of primer: acrylic, alkyd, deep-penetrating, universal. Calculation formula: Amount of primer = (Wall area - Opening area) × Consumption rate (l/m²) × (1 + Stock / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Primer calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the amount of primer for various rooms and types of primer:

example1.title: Example 1: Bedroom 4x3 meters
example1.description: Standard bedroom with ceiling height 2.7 m, acrylic primer
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window: 1.2×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption rate: 0.1 l/m²
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Opening area: 1.2×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 3.6 m²
Usable area: 37.8 - 3.6 = 34.2 m²
Primer consumption: 34.2 × 0.1 = 3.42 l
With reserve: 3.42 × 1.1 = 3.76 l
Packs (10 l): 3.76 / 10 = 0.38 ≈ 1 pack
example1.note: Standard bedroom, it is recommended to take 1 package with a small margin

example2.title: Example 2: Living room 5x4 meters
example2.description: Large living room with ceiling height 2.7 m, universal primer
example2.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 pieces, 1.5×1.5 m each
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (5 + 4) × 2.7 = 48.6 m²
Opening area: 2×1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 6.3 m²
Usable area: 48.6 - 6.3 = 42.3 m²
Primer consumption: 42.3 × 0.12 = 5.08 l
With reserve: 5.08 × 1.15 = 5.84 l
Packs (10 l): 5.84 / 10 = 0.58 ≈ 1 pack
example2.note: For a large room, an increased margin of 15% is recommended.

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3x2.5 meters
example3.description: Kitchen with a ceiling height of 2.5 m, deep-penetrating primer
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window: 1.2×1.2 m
Door: 0.8×2.0 m
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (3 + 2.5) × 2.5 = 27.5 m²
Opening area: 1.2×1.2 + 0.8×2.0 = 3.04 m²
Usable area: 27.5 - 3.04 = 24.46 m²
Primer consumption: 24.46 × 0.12 = 2.94 l
With reserve: 2.94 × 1.1 = 3.23 l
Packs (5 l): 3.23 / 5 = 0.65 ≈ 1 pack
example3.note: A deep-penetrating primer is recommended for the kitchen.

example4.title: Example 4: Children's room 4x3.5 meters
example4.description: Children's room with ceiling height 2.6 m, acrylic primer
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.6 m
Window: 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption rate: 0.1 l/m²
Stock: 10%
example4.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3.5) × 2.6 = 39.0 m²
Opening area: 1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 4.05 m²
Usable area: 39.0 - 4.05 = 34.95 m²
Primer consumption: 34.95 × 0.1 = 3.5 l
With reserve: 3.5 × 1.1 = 3.85 l
Packs (5 l): 3.85 / 5 = 0.77 ≈ 1 pack
example4.note: An eco-friendly acrylic primer is recommended for children's rooms.

example5.title: Example 5: Ceiling 6x5 meters
example5.description: Large ceiling, universal primer
example5.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m
Ceiling area: 30 m²
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 15%
example5.calculation:
Usable area: 30 m²
Primer consumption: 30 × 0.12 = 3.6 l
With reserve: 3.6 × 1.15 = 4.14 l
Packs (5 l): 4.14 / 5 = 0.83 ≈ 1 pack
example5.note: For the ceiling, an increased margin of 15% is recommended

example6.title: Example 6: Bathroom 2x1.5 meters
example6.description: Small bathroom with a ceiling height of 2.5 m, moisture-resistant primer
example6.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption rate: 0.12 l/m²
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (2 + 1.5) × 2.5 = 17.5 m²
Opening area: 0.9×2.0 = 1.8 m²
Usable area: 17.5 - 1.8 = 15.7 m²
Primer consumption: 15.7 × 0.12 = 1.88 l
With reserve: 1.88 × 1.1 = 2.07 l
Packs (5 l): 2.07 / 5 = 0.41 ≈ 1 pack
example6.note: The bathroom requires a moisture-resistant primer

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of primer?
faqItems.a: To calculate the primer, measure the length, width and height of the walls of the room, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors, multiply by the consumption rate (usually 0.08-0.15 l/m²) and add a margin of 10-15%. The calculator will automatically perform all calculations.

faqItems.q: How much primer is needed per 1 m²?
faqItems.a: Primer consumption is usually 0.08-0.12 l/m² for smooth surfaces and 0.12-0.15 l/m² for porous surfaces. The primer is applied in one layer.

faqItems.q: How many coats of primer are needed?
faqItems.a: Typically the primer is applied in one layer. Highly porous surfaces may require a second coat. In such cases, the consumption doubles.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between acrylic and alkyd primer?
faqItems.a: Acrylic primer is universal, suitable for various surfaces (consumption 0.08-0.12 l/m²). Alkyd primer is used for wood and metal (consumption 0.1-0.15 l/m²). The quantity calculation for both types is the same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for a bedroom?
faqItems.a: For a bedroom, measure the dimensions of the room, indicate the area of ​​windows and doors. Use acrylic or universal primer. Consumption rate 0.1 l/m². Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for a ceiling?
faqItems.a: For the ceiling, measure the ceiling area in square meters. Ceilings usually require more primer due to the difficulty of application. Use a consumption rate of 0.1-0.12 l/m². Add a margin of 15%.

faqItems.q: Which primer is best for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls, it is recommended to use an acrylic or universal primer for various surfaces. For wet areas, use a moisture-resistant primer. For porous surfaces, use a deep-penetrating primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for the kitchen?
faqItems.a: For the kitchen, use a moisture-resistant acrylic or deep-penetrating primer. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Use a consumption rate of 0.12 l/m² for wet areas. Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much does a package of primer weigh?
faqItems.a: A standard 5 liter package of primer weighs approximately 5-7 kg. A 10 liter package weighs approximately 10-14 kg. There are also packages of 1 l, 2.5 l and 20 l.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for a bathroom?
faqItems.a: For the bathroom, use a moisture-resistant, deep-penetrating primer. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​the door. Use a consumption rate of 0.12-0.15 l/m² for wet rooms. Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: What is a deep penetrating primer?
faqItems.a: A deep-penetrating primer penetrates deep into the pores of the material, strengthens the surface and improves adhesion. Consumption is 0.1-0.15 l/m². Used for loose and porous surfaces.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for a living room?
faqItems.a: For the living room, measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Use acrylic or universal primer. Consumption rate 0.1 l/m². Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: Do windows and doors need to be taken into account when calculating the primer?
faqItems.a: Yes, be sure to take all windows and doors into account when calculating your primer. Subtracting the area of ​​the openings from the total area of ​​the walls allows you to obtain the exact usable area for processing and avoid wastage of material.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for a children's room?
faqItems.a: For a children's room, measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. It is recommended to use an environmentally friendly acrylic primer. Use a consumption rate of 0.1 l/m². Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: What is a universal primer?
faqItems.a: A universal primer suitable for various types of surfaces (concrete, plaster, plasterboard, wood). It is convenient for small jobs. Consumption is 0.1-0.12 l/m². The calculation of the quantity is the same as for a regular primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the primer for a corridor?
faqItems.a: For the corridor, measure the length and width, the height of the ceilings. Consider all the doors in the hallway. Use a consumption rate of 0.1-0.12 l/m². Add 10-15% margin for adjustment.

faqItems.q: How much primer is needed for a 20 m² room?
faqItems.a: For a room with an area of ​​20 m² (approximately 4 × 5 m) with a standard ceiling height of 2.7 m, you need approximately 3-4 liters of primer (1 package 5 liters), taking into account a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for a studio?
faqItems.a: For a studio, measure the area of ​​all walls. Consider all windows and doors. Select the type of primer depending on the zoning. For open spaces, use a universal primer. Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is an antiseptic primer?
faqItems.a: Antiseptic primer contains substances that prevent the formation of mold and mildew. Consumption is 0.12-0.15 l/m². Used for wet rooms and rooms with high humidity. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for a regular primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for a toilet?
faqItems.a: For the toilet, measure the area of ​​the walls. Subtract the area of ​​the door. Use a moisture-resistant antiseptic primer. Consider the small area of ​​the room. Use a flow rate of 0.12 l/m². Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: Which primer is best for painting?
faqItems.a: For painting, it is recommended to use an acrylic or universal white primer. It creates a uniform base for paint, consumption 0.1-0.12 l/m². After priming, wait until completely dry before painting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the primer for an entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For an apartment, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of primer for different rooms (moisture-resistant for kitchens and bathrooms, regular for living rooms). Add up the results for the total number of packages.

faqItems.q: Do I need to buy extra primer?
faqItems.a: Yes, be sure to buy a primer with a margin of 10-15% for adjustment, defects and possible errors during application. A stock will help avoid a situation where there is a small quantity missing and it is difficult to find exactly the same one in the store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for a hallway?
faqItems.a: For the hallway, measure the area of ​​the walls. Consider all doors. Use a wear-resistant, high-traffic primer. Use a consumption rate of 0.1-0.12 l/m². Add 10-15% margin for adjustment.

faqItems.q: What is an adhesion primer?
faqItems.a: Adhesive primer improves the adhesion of materials to the surface. Consumption is 0.1-0.15 l/m². Used on smooth surfaces before painting or wallpapering. The calculation of the quantity is the same as for a regular primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for a home?
faqItems.a: For a house, calculate the area of ​​each room separately. Use different types of primer for different spaces. Add up the results for the total number of packages. Keep in mind that for large rooms it is better to buy primer in bulk.

faqItems.q: How long does it take for primer to dry?
faqItems.a: The drying time of the primer depends on the type and conditions. Acrylic primer dries in 4-6 hours, alkyd - 12-24 hours, deep-penetrating - 2-4 hours. Consider drying time when planning your work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for porous surfaces?
faqItems.a: For porous surfaces, increase the consumption rate to 0.12-0.15 l/m², add a margin of 15-20% to the usual calculation. Consider the possibility that a second coat may be necessary for highly porous surfaces.

faqItems.q: What is white primer?
faqItems.a: A white primer is used before painting with light colors to avoid the dark surface showing through. The consumption is the same as for a regular primer - 0.1-0.12 l/m². It costs more than a colorless primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the primer for repair?
faqItems.a: To make repairs, measure the area of ​​walls or ceilings that need to be primed. Use the application rate depending on the type of primer. Add a margin of 10-15% for adjustment and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What is the consumption rate of primer for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls, the primer consumption rate is 0.08-0.12 l/m² for smooth surfaces and 0.12-0.15 l/m² for porous surfaces. This is the average cost for most types of acrylic and all-purpose primers when applied correctly.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a primer for wallpaper?
faqItems.a: To prepare walls for wallpaper, use an acrylic or universal primer. Measure the area of ​​the walls, subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Use a consumption rate of 0.1-0.12 l/m². Add a margin of 10%.

faqItems.q: What is clear primer?
faqItems.a: A clear primer is used to protect the surface without changing its color. The consumption is the same as for a regular primer - 0.1-0.12 l/m². Used before gluing wallpaper or applying decorative coatings.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for drywall?
faqItems.a: For drywall, use acrylic or all-purpose primer. Measure the area of ​​the walls. Use a consumption rate of 0.1-0.12 l/m². Add a margin of 10-15% to take into account the porosity of the drywall.

step4.name: Establish stock

step5.name: Get the result
step5.text: The calculator will automatically calculate the required amount of primer in liters and packages

overview.title: Plaster calculator
overview.content: An online plaster calculator will help you calculate the required amount of plaster for finishing walls. The dimensions of the room, the thickness of the layer, the type of plaster, the number of layers and the margin for losses are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The plaster calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the amount of material taking into account the type of surface, application method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various types of plaster: cement, gypsum, decorative, lime. Calculation formula: Total amount of plaster = (Area of ​​walls - Area of ​​doors and windows) × Consumption rate (kg/m²) × Number of layers × (1 + Stock / 100). The consumption rate depends on the layer thickness: usually 8-10 kg/m² per 1 mm of layer thickness.

calculationExamples.title: Plaster calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the amount of plaster for various rooms and types of plaster:

example1.title: Example 1: Room 4x3 meters, gypsum plaster
example1.description: Standard room with ceiling height 2.7 m, gypsum plaster, layer thickness 10 mm
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window and door area: 4.5 m²
Number of layers: 1
Consumption rate: 9 kg/m² (gypsum, 10 mm)
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Usable area: 37.8 - 4.5 = 33.3 m²
Consumption per layer: 33.3 × 9 = 299.7 kg
Total consumption: 299.7 × 1 × 1.1 = 329.7 kg
example1.result: Required: 329.7 kg (11 bags of 30 kg each)
example1.note: Gypsum plaster is easier to apply and dries faster, suitable for interior work

example2.title: Example 2: Large living room, cement plaster
example2.description: Spacious living room with large windows, cement plaster for the facade, layer thickness 15 mm
example2.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 3 m
Window and door area: 12 m²
Number of layers: 1
Consumption rate: 17 kg/m² (cement, 15 mm)
Stock: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (6 + 5) × 3 = 66 m²
Usable area: 66 - 12 = 54 m²
Consumption per layer: 54 × 17 = 918 kg
Total consumption: 918 × 1 × 1.15 = 1,055.7 kg
example2.result: Required: 1,055.7 kg (36 bags of 30 kg each)
example2.note: Cement plaster is more durable, suitable for outdoor use and wet areas

example3.title: Example 3: Studio apartment, decorative plaster
example3.description: Modern studio, decorative plaster to create texture, thin layer
example3.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window and door area: 8 m²
Number of layers: 1
Consumption rate: 8 kg/m² (decorative, 5 mm)
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (5 + 4) × 2.5 = 45 m²
Usable area: 45 - 8 = 37 m²
Consumption per layer: 37 × 8 = 296 kg
Total consumption: 296 × 1 × 1.1 = 325.6 kg
example3.result: Required: 325.6 kg (11 bags of 30 kg each)
example3.note: Decorative plaster is applied in a thin layer, creating a unique surface texture

example4.title: Example 4: Corridor with two layers, lime plaster
example4.description: Narrow corridor, lime plaster in two layers for reliability
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.7 m
Door area: 3 m²
Number of layers: 2
Consumption rate: 10 kg/m² (lime, 10 mm)
Stock: 10%
example4.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (4 + 1.5) × 2.7 = 29.7 m²
Usable area: 29.7 - 3 = 26.7 m²
Consumption per layer: 26.7 × 10 = 267 kg
Total consumption: 267 × 2 × 1.1 = 587.4 kg
example4.result: Required: 587.4 kg (20 bags of 30 kg each)
example4.note: Lime plaster is breathable and environmentally friendly, well suited for residential premises

example5.title: Example 5: Bathroom, cement plaster with waterproofing
example5.description: Bathroom with high humidity, cement plaster to protect against water
example5.input:
Length: 2.5 m, Width: 2 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door area: 2 m²
Number of layers: 1
Consumption rate: 17 kg/m² (cement, 15 mm)
Stock: 15%
example5.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (2.5 + 2) × 2.5 = 22.5 m²
Usable area: 22.5 - 2 = 20.5 m²
Consumption per layer: 20.5 × 17 = 348.5 kg
Total consumption: 348.5 × 1 × 1.15 = 400.8 kg
example5.result: Required: 400.8 kg (14 bags of 30 kg each)
example5.note: Cement plaster is recommended for bathrooms due to its high moisture resistance

example6.title: Example 6: Cottage, facade cement plaster
example6.description: External walls of the cottage, cement plaster for protection from weather conditions, thick layer
example6.input:
Length: 10 m, Width: 8 m, Height: 3 m
Window and door area: 15 m²
Number of layers: 1
Consumption rate: 25 kg/m² (cement, 20 mm)
Stock: 20%
example6.calculation:
Wall area: 2 × (10 + 8) × 3 = 108 m²
Usable area: 108 - 15 = 93 m²
Consumption per layer: 93 × 25 = 2.325 kg
Total consumption: 2.325 × 1 × 1.2 = 2.790 kg
example6.note: For facades, thicker layers of plaster are used to protect against moisture and temperature changes

calculation.title: How is the amount of plaster calculated?
calculation.content: Calculation of plaster includes several stages to obtain an accurate result depending on the type of plaster, layer thickness and working conditions.
calculation.usefulArea: Usable area = Area of ​​walls - Area of ​​doors and windows
calculation.consumption: Consumption per layer = Usable area × Consumption rate (kg/m²)
calculation.total: Total consumption = Consumption per layer × Number of layers × (1 + Stock / 100)
