tips.title: Tips for working with plaster
tips.content: To obtain high-quality results when working with plaster, follow our recommendations:

preparation.clean: Clean the surface from dust, dirt and old coatings
preparation.prime: Prime the surface to improve adhesion.
preparation.level: Install beacons for even application of plaster

application.thickness: Follow the recommended layer thickness (usually 10-15 mm)
application.layers: If necessary, apply the plaster in several layers, allowing drying between layers.
application.drying: Allow the plaster to dry completely before further finishing.

optimization.type: Choose the type of plaster depending on the room (gypsum for dry, cement for wet)
optimization.tools: Use the right tools (trowel, spatula, trowel) for a good application.
optimization.reserve: Always add a margin of 10-15% for losses and surface unevenness

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of plaster for walls?
faqItems.a: To calculate the plaster, measure the length and width of the room and the height of the walls. Calculate the wall area: 2 × (Length + Width) × Height. Subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Multiply by the consumption rate (usually 9-17 kg/m²) and the number of layers. Add 10-15% reserve.

faqItems.q: How much plaster is needed per 1 m² of wall?
faqItems.a: The consumption of plaster depends on the thickness of the layer: with a thickness of 10 mm, the consumption is 8-10 kg/m² for gypsum plaster and 15-17 kg/m² for cement plaster. For every additional millimeter of thickness, approximately 0.8-1 kg/m² is added for gypsum and 1.5-1.7 kg/m² for cement.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between gypsum and cement plaster?
faqItems.a: Gypsum plaster is lighter, dries faster (1-2 days), and is suitable for dry rooms. Cement plaster is stronger, moisture-resistant, takes longer to dry (5-7 days), and is used for wet rooms and facades. The consumption of cement plaster is higher due to its higher density.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for a facade?
faqItems.a: For the facade, use cement plaster with a consumption rate of 17-25 kg/m² depending on the thickness of the layer (usually 15-20 mm). Please note that facades require a larger margin (15-20%) due to wind, rain and losses when working at height.

faqItems.q: How much plaster is needed for a room of 20 m²?
faqItems.a: For a room of 20 m² (for example, 5 × 4 m) with a wall height of 2.7 m, the wall area will be approximately 48.6 m². With a consumption rate of 9 kg/m² (gypsum, 10 mm) and a reserve of 10%, you need: 48.6 × 9 × 1.1 = 481 kg (16 bags of 30 kg each).

faqItems.q: How to calculate decorative plaster?
faqItems.a: Decorative plaster is applied in a thin layer (3-5 mm), so the consumption is less: 6-10 kg/m². To calculate, multiply the area of ​​the walls by the consumption rate, taking into account the texture (relief textures require more material). Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: Can gypsum plaster be used in damp areas?
faqItems.a: No, gypsum plaster is not suitable for wet areas (bathroom, kitchen, basement). In wet rooms, use cement plaster with the addition of waterproofing additives. Gypsum plaster absorbs moisture and deteriorates.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster taking into account lighthouses?
faqItems.a: Beacons do not affect the consumption of plaster; they are only needed for leveling. Consumption is calculated using the same formula: wall area × consumption rate. Beacons are installed to control the thickness of the layer and are not taken into account in the calculation of the material.

faqItems.q: How long does it take for plaster to dry before painting?
faqItems.a: Gypsum plaster dries in 1-2 days, cement plaster - 5-7 days. Complete drying before painting is required, otherwise the paint may peel off. Drying time depends on layer thickness, temperature and air humidity.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for a ceiling?
faqItems.a: For the ceiling, use the ceiling area (Length × Width). The consumption rate is the same as for walls: 9-17 kg/m² depending on the type. Keep in mind that working on the ceiling can increase losses by 5-10%, add a larger margin.

faqItems.q: What is rough and finishing plaster?
faqItems.a: Rough plaster (spray and primer) - base layer for leveling, consumption 15-20 kg/m². Finishing plaster (covering) - a thin layer of 2-5 mm for final finishing, consumption 3-5 kg/m². Usually used together.

faqItems.q: How to calculate warm plaster?
faqItems.a: Warm plaster contains insulating additives (perlite, vermiculite), consumption 10-12 kg/m² with a thickness of 10 mm. It is calculated similarly to conventional plaster: area × consumption rate × number of layers × (1 + reserve).

faqItems.q: How much plaster in a 30 kg bag is enough for how many m²?
faqItems.a: A 30 kg bag of gypsum plaster at a consumption rate of 9 kg/m² (10 mm layer) is enough for 3.3 m². A bag of cement plaster at a rate of 17 kg/m² (15 mm layer) is enough for 1.8 m². Calculation: 30 / consumption rate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for a room with columns?
faqItems.a: For columns, calculate the area as perimeter x height and add to the total area of ​​the walls. Use standard application rate. Columns can have complex shapes; add a margin of 15-20% for processing corners and curved surfaces.

faqItems.q: Is a primer necessary before plastering?
faqItems.a: Yes, primer is required before plastering. It improves the adhesion of the plaster to the surface, prevents water absorption and increases the strength of the coating. Primer consumption: 0.1-0.15 l/m², taken into account separately from the plaster.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for a room with a bay window?
faqItems.a: For a bay window, measure the area of ​​all the bay window walls and add to the total area. A bay window adds extra space. Use standard application rate. Keep in mind that the corners of the bay window may require more material, add a margin of 15%.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to apply plaster in one layer?
faqItems.a: For thin layers (up to 10 mm) it can be applied in one layer. For thick layers (15-20 mm) it is recommended to apply two layers to prevent cracking. The first layer is rough, the second is finishing.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for concrete walls?
faqItems.a: Concrete walls require preliminary preparation (priming, notching for adhesion). Plaster consumption is standard: 9-17 kg/m² depending on the type. The concrete may be uneven, add a 15% margin for leveling.

faqItems.q: How much plaster is needed for a two-room apartment?
faqItems.a: For a two-room apartment with an area of ​​50-60 m² with a ceiling height of 2.7 m, the total wall area will be approximately 120-150 m². At a consumption rate of 9 kg/m² you need: 120 × 9 × 1.1 = 1.188 kg (40 bags of 30 kg) for all walls.

faqItems.q: How to calculate mechanical plaster?
faqItems.a: Mechanical plaster is applied by machine, the consumption is the same as for manual application: 9-17 kg/m². The advantage of mechanical plaster is the speed and uniformity of the layer, which reduces losses. The margin can be reduced to 5-10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster using a grid?
faqItems.a: Grid plaster is used to strengthen the coating. Consumption increases by 10-15% due to the filling of the mesh cells. Use an application rate of 10-19 kg/m² instead of the standard 9-17 kg/m² when working on a grid.

faqItems.q: How long does it take for gypsum plaster to dry before wallpapering?
faqItems.a: Gypsum plaster dries in 1-2 days, but before gluing wallpaper you need to wait for complete drying - 3-5 days depending on the thickness of the layer. Wet plaster under wallpaper can lead to mold.

faqItems.q: How to calculate lime plaster?
faqItems.a: Lime plaster has a consumption of 8-12 kg/m² with a layer thickness of 10 mm. It is lighter than cement, environmentally friendly, breathable. It is calculated similarly: area × consumption rate × number of layers × (1 + reserve). Suitable for residential premises.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to plaster in winter?
faqItems.a: Plaster can be applied in winter only at temperatures above +5°C and using anti-frost additives for cement plaster. Gypsum plaster is not used at subzero temperatures. In winter, drying time increases.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for a room with niches?
faqItems.a: For a room with niches, measure the area of ​​the niche walls and add to the total area. Niches increase the area for plaster. Use standard application rate. Corners and complex niche shapes may require more material, add a 15% margin.

faqItems.q: How much does it cost to apply plaster per m²?
faqItems.a: The cost of plastering work depends on the type of surface and region. On average: rough plaster 300-500 ₽/m², finishing plaster 400-700 ₽/m². Decorative plaster is more expensive: 800-1,500 RUR/m². Prices do not include materials.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for a balcony?
faqItems.a: For a balcony, use cement or facade plaster with a consumption rate of 17-25 kg/m². Measure the area of ​​all balcony walls, including railings. Keep in mind that balconies are subject to temperature changes, use a margin of 15-20%.

faqItems.q: What is ready-mixed plaster?
faqItems.a: Ready-made plaster is sold as a ready-made paste in buckets. The consumption of the finished plaster is indicated on the packaging, usually 1.5-2.5 kg/m² with a layer thickness of 1 mm. It is more convenient to use, but more expensive than dry mixtures.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for textured ceilings?
faqItems.a: For textured ceilings, consumption increases by 20-30% due to the relief. Use a consumption rate of 11-22 kg/m² instead of the standard 9-17 kg/m², depending on the depth of the texture. Textured surfaces require more material to fill.

faqItems.q: How much plaster is needed for a 100 m² house?
faqItems.a: For a house of 100 m² with a ceiling height of 3 m, the total wall area will be approximately 360 m² (for a square house 10x10 m). With a consumption rate of 9 kg/m² and a reserve of 10%, you need: 360 × 9 × 1.1 = 3.564 kg (119 bags of 30 kg) for all walls.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for clay walls?
faqItems.a: Clay walls require special preparation before plastering (strengthening, priming). Standard consumption: 9-17 kg/m². Clay walls may be uneven, add a margin of 15-20%. It is recommended to use lime or cement plaster.

overview.title: Foundation calculator
overview.content: An online foundation calculator will help you calculate the required amount of materials for building a foundation. Supports the calculation of strip, slab and column foundations. Takes into account the volume of concrete, the amount of reinforcement, the area of ​​the formwork and all the necessary materials.
overview.additionalContent: The foundation calculator uses precise formulas to calculate concrete volume, reinforcement weight, and formwork area. Suitable for calculating various types of foundations: strip (for houses), slab (for uniform load), columnar (for light structures). Calculation formula: Volume of concrete = Area × Height (each type of foundation has its own formula). Reinforcement is calculated based on the volume of concrete and reinforcement density.

calculationExamples.title: Foundation calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating materials for various types of foundations:

example1.title: Example 1: Strip foundation for a house 6x8 m
example1.description: Strip foundation for a one-story house, depth 1.5 m
example1.input:
Type: Tape
Length: 8 m, Width: 6 m, Height: 1.5 m
Wall thickness: 0.4 m
Concrete grade: M200
Reinforcement: 12 mm, pitch 20 cm, 2 layers
Stock: 10%
example1.result: Concrete: 16.37 m³, Cement: 92 bags, Reinforcement: 1,640 kg
example1.note: Strip foundations are the most common for private houses and provide reliable support.

example2.title: Example 2: Slab foundation for a house 10x10 m
example2.description: Monolithic slab for a two-story house, thickness 30 cm
example2.input:
Type: Slab
Length: 10 m, Width: 10 m, Thickness: 0.3 m
Concrete grade: M250
Reinforcement: 14 mm, pitch 20 cm, 2 layers
Stock: 10%
example2.calculation:
Volume: 10 × 10 × 0.3 = 30 m³
With reserve: 30 × 1.1 = 33 m³
Cement: 33 × 330 = 10.890 kg (218 bags)
Sand: 33 × 720 = 23.760 kg
Crushed stone: 33 × 1250 = 41.250 kg
Reinforcement: ~3,300 kg (275 bars of 12 m each)
example2.result: Concrete: 33 m³, Cement: 218 bags, Reinforcement: 3,300 kg
example2.note: Slab foundation distributes the load evenly, suitable for weak soils

example3.title: Example 3: Columnar foundation for a 4×4 m bathhouse
example3.description: Columnar foundation for a bathhouse, 9 pillars
example3.input:
Type: Columnar
Quantity: 9 pillars
Pole size: 0.4×0.4 m, Height: 1.2 m
Concrete grade: M200
Reinforcement: 10 mm, pitch 15 cm, 1 layer
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Volume of one column: 0.4 × 0.4 × 1.2 = 0.192 m³
Total volume: 0.192 × 9 = 1.728 m³
With reserve: 1.728 × 1.1 = 1.9 m³
Cement: 1.9 × 280 = 532 kg (11 bags)
Sand: 1.9 × 730 = 1.387 kg
Crushed stone: 1.9 × 1250 = 2.375 kg
Reinforcement: ~190 kg (16 rods of 12 m each)
example3.result: Concrete: 1.9 m³, Cement: 11 bags, Reinforcement: 190 kg
example3.note: Columnar foundation is economical for light buildings, quickly erected

example4.title: Example 4: Shallow strip foundation
example4.description: Strip foundation for a one-story frame house
example4.input:
Type: Tape
Length: 8 m, Width: 6 m, Height: 0.6 m (shallow)
Wall thickness: 0.3 m
Concrete grade: M200
Reinforcement: 10 mm, pitch 25 cm, 2 layers
Stock: 10%
example4.result: Concrete: 2.42 m³, Cement: 14 bags, Reinforcement: 242 kg
example4.note: Shallow foundation suitable for stable soils and lightweight structures

example5.title: Example 5: Slab foundation with insulation
example5.description: Insulated board for an energy-efficient home
example5.input:
Type: Slab
Length: 12 m, Width: 10 m, Thickness: 0.25 m
Concrete grade: M300
Reinforcement: 16 mm, pitch 15 cm, 2 layers
Stock: 15%
example5.calculation:
Volume: 12 × 10 × 0.25 = 30 m³
With reserve: 30 × 1.15 = 34.5 m³
Cement: 34.5 × 380 = 13,110 kg (263 bags)
Sand: 34.5 × 700 = 24.150 kg
Crushed stone: 34.5 × 1250 = 43.125 kg
Reinforcement: ~3,450 kg (288 bars of 12 m each)
example5.result: Concrete: 34.5 m³, Cement: 263 bags, Reinforcement: 3,450 kg
example5.note: An insulated slab foundation ensures energy efficiency and comfort in the home

example6.title: Example 6: Pillar foundation for a terrace
example6.description: Columnar foundation for an open terrace
example6.input:
Type: Columnar
Quantity: 6 pillars
Pole size: 0.3×0.3 m, Height: 0.8 m
Concrete grade: M200
Reinforcement: 8 mm, pitch 20 cm, 1 layer
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Volume of one column: 0.3 × 0.3 × 0.8 = 0.072 m³
Total volume: 0.072 × 6 = 0.432 m³
With a margin: 0.432 × 1.1 = 0.475 m³
Cement: 0.475 × 280 = 133 kg (3 bags)
Sand: 0.475 × 730 = 346.75 kg
Crushed stone: 0.475 × 1250 = 593.75 kg
Reinforcement: ~47.5 kg (4 rods of 12 m each)
example6.result: Concrete: 0.475 m³, Cement: 3 bags, Reinforcement: 47.5 kg
example6.note: Columnar foundations are ideal for open areas and lightweight superstructures

calculation.title: How foundation materials are calculated
calculation.content: Calculation of materials for the foundation includes several stages depending on the type of foundation, concrete grade and reinforcement parameters.
calculation.strip: Tape: V = (L×W×H) - ((L-2t)×(W-2t)×H), where L is length, W is width, H is height, t is wall thickness
calculation.slab: Slab: V = L×W×T, where L is length, W is width, T is slab thickness
calculation.columnar: Columnar: V = N×L×W×H, where N is the number of columns, L×W×H is the dimensions of one column
calculation.materials: Materials: Cement = V×Cement_Rate(grade), Sand = V×Sand_Rate(grade), Crushed stone = V×Crushed_Rate(grade)

advantages.title: Benefits of using a calculator
advantages.content: Using a foundation calculator provides many benefits when planning a construction project.

accuracy.title: Accuracy of calculations
accuracy.description: The calculator takes into account all parameters: foundation type, dimensions, concrete grade, reinforcement parameters. This guarantees an accurate calculation without overpayments or material shortages.

savings.title: Saving money
savings.description: Correct calculation allows you to buy the exact amount of materials without excess. Savings can amount to 10-15% of the cost of foundation materials.

planning.title: Procurement planning
planning.description: Knowing the exact amount of concrete, reinforcement and formwork, you can plan the purchase of materials in advance and avoid work stoppages due to material shortages.

tips.title: Tips for building a foundation
tips.content: To get a high-quality foundation, follow our recommendations:

preparation.soil: Conduct a geological study of the soil before design
preparation.level: Level the site and prepare a bed of sand and crushed stone
preparation.drainage: Provide drainage to move water away from the foundation

reinforcement.diameter: Choose the diameter of the reinforcement depending on the load (10-16 mm for private houses)
reinforcement.spacing: Maintain reinforcement spacing of 15-25 cm for optimal reinforcement
reinforcement.layers: Use at least 2 layers of reinforcement for strip and slab foundations

concreting.grade: Choose the grade of concrete depending on the load (M200 for light, M250-M300 for heavy structures)
concreting.mixing: Mix concrete in the correct proportions or use ready-made
concreting.curing: Ensure proper curing of concrete (watering, covering) for 28 days

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of concrete for the foundation?
faqItems.a: To calculate concrete, determine the volume of the foundation. For tape: volume = (length×width×height) - (internal volume). For slab: volume = length×width×thickness. For columnar: volume = quantity × column size. Then multiply by the grade of concrete and add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much concrete is needed for a 10x10 m foundation?
faqItems.a: For a strip foundation 10x10 m with a depth of 1.5 m and a wall thickness of 0.4 m, the volume will be approximately 22 m³. Taking into account the 10% reserve, 24.2 m³ of concrete is needed. For a slab foundation 30 cm thick, you need 30 m³ (10 × 10 × 0.3) plus a margin.

faqItems.q: How to calculate reinforcement for a foundation?
faqItems.a: Reinforcement is calculated based on the volume of concrete and reinforcement density. Typically, 100-150 kg of reinforcement are used per 1 m³ of concrete. For a strip foundation, use reinforcement with a diameter of 10-14 mm in increments of 15-25 cm in 2 layers (top and bottom).

faqItems.q: What brand of concrete should I use for the foundation?
faqItems.a: For private houses, they usually use M200 (lightweight structures) or M250 (two-story houses). For heavy structures and multi-story buildings, M300 is used. M200 contains 280 kg of cement per m³, M250 - 330 kg, M300 - 380 kg.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a strip foundation?
faqItems.a: For a strip foundation, measure the perimeter of the house and multiply by the width and depth of the foundation. Subtract the internal volume. Example: house 8×10 m, perimeter 36 m, width 0.4 m, depth 1.5 m → volume = 36×0.4×1.5 = 21.6 m³. Subtract the internal volume of the walls.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a slab foundation?
faqItems.a: For a slab foundation, volume = length × width × thickness. The thickness of the slab is usually 20-40 cm depending on the load. Example: house 10×12 m, thickness 30 cm → volume = 10×12×0.3 = 36 m³. Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a columnar foundation?
faqItems.a: For a columnar foundation, calculate the volume of one column (length × width × height) and multiply by the number of columns. Typically, pillars are installed in the corners and every 1.5-2 m. Example: 9 pillars 0.4×0.4×1.2 m → volume = 9×0.192 = 1.73 m³.

faqItems.q: How much reinforcement is needed for a foundation?
faqItems.a: The amount of reinforcement depends on the type of foundation and load. For a strip foundation, usually 100-150 kg of reinforcement per 1 m³ of concrete. For a slab foundation - 50-80 kg/m³. For columnar - 80-120 kg/m³. Reinforcement diameter: 10-14 mm for private houses.

faqItems.q: What is the depth of the foundation for a house?
faqItems.a: The depth of the foundation depends on the type of soil and the depth of freezing. For a strip foundation, usually 1.5-2 m (20 cm below the freezing depth). For a slab foundation, the depth depends on the thickness of the slab (20-40 cm). For columnar - 1-1.5 m.

faqItems.q: How to calculate formwork for a foundation?
faqItems.a: Formwork area = foundation perimeter × height × 2 (inner and outer side). For a strip foundation, perimeter = 2 × (length + width). For slab formwork only around the perimeter. Example: house 8×10 m, height 1.5 m → perimeter 36 m, formwork area = 36×1.5×2 = 108 m².

faqItems.q: What is a shallow foundation?
faqItems.a: The shallow foundation has a depth of 40-70 cm (above the freezing depth). Suitable for stable soils and light structures (frame houses, bathhouses). Requires less concrete and reinforcement, is faster to build, but less stable on heaving soils.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a bathhouse?
faqItems.a: For a bathhouse, a columnar or shallow strip foundation is usually used. Columnar: 6-9 pillars measuring 0.3×0.3 m, depth 0.8-1 m. Shallow strip: depth 0.5-0.7 m, width 0.3 m. The volume of concrete for a bathhouse 4×4 m will be 1-2 m³.

faqItems.q: How much does a foundation cost for a 100 m² house?
faqItems.a: The cost of the foundation depends on the type and region. Strip foundation for a house of 100 m²: volume of concrete 20-25 m³ × 4000-5000 ₽/m³ = 80,000-125,000 ₽. Reinforcement: 2-3 tons × 50,000 ₽/t = 100,000-150,000 ₽. Work: 1,500-2,500 ₽/m³. Total: 300,000-500,000 ₽.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a garage?
faqItems.a: For a garage, a strip or slab foundation is usually used. Tape: perimeter × width × depth (usually 0.5-0.7 m). Slab: garage area × thickness (15-20 cm). For a 6x4 m garage, a strip foundation will require 2-3 m³ of concrete, a slab foundation - 4.8-6.4 m³.

faqItems.q: Do you need reinforcement in the foundation?
faqItems.a: Yes, reinforcement is required for all types of foundations. It provides strength and prevents cracks. Without reinforcement, the foundation may crack due to soil shrinkage or load. Minimum reinforcement: diameter 10 mm, pitch 20-25 cm, minimum 2 layers (top and bottom).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the pillow for the foundation?
faqItems.a: The foundation cushion consists of sand (20-30 cm) and crushed stone (10-15 cm). Pillow area = foundation area. Volume of sand = area × 0.25 m. Volume of crushed stone = area × 0.15 m. Example: foundation 8 × 10 m → sand 20 m³, crushed stone 12 m³.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a two-story house?
faqItems.a: A two-story house needs a stronger foundation. Use a recessed strip (depth 1.5-2 m) or slab (thickness 30-40 cm). Concrete grade M250-M300. Reinforcement with a diameter of 12-16 mm. The volume of concrete for a 10x12 m house will be 25-35 m³, depending on the type of foundation.

faqItems.q: How long does it take for the foundation to dry?
faqItems.a: The foundation gains strength in 28 days. The first 3 days require constant humidity (watering 2-3 times a day). After 7 days you can remove the formwork. After 14 days, you can begin laying the walls. Full strength is achieved after 28 days.

faqItems.q: How to calculate a foundation on a slope?
faqItems.a: For a slope, a stepped strip foundation or pile foundation is usually used. Calculate each step separately. Volume = the sum of the volumes of all stages. The fittings are calculated based on the total volume. Consider the need for drainage and slope strengthening.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation waterproofing?
faqItems.a: Waterproofing area = area of ​​vertical foundation surfaces. For tape: perimeter × height. For slab: perimeter × thickness + base area. Consumption of roll waterproofing: 1.1-1.2 m² per 1 m² of surface (including overlap).

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation insulation?
faqItems.a: Insulation area = area of ​​vertical foundation surfaces. For tape: perimeter × height. Use extruded polystyrene foam 5-10 cm thick. Consumption: foundation area × insulation thickness. Example: perimeter 36 m, height 1.5 m → area 54 m², insulation volume 10 cm = 5.4 m³.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to pour the foundation in winter?
faqItems.a: Pouring the foundation in winter is possible at temperatures above -5°C using anti-frost additives and insulation. At temperatures below -5°C, concrete heating and formwork insulation are required. It is recommended to pour the foundation in the warm season for better quality.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a frame house?
faqItems.a: A shallow strip or column foundation is suitable for a frame house. Strip: depth 0.5-0.7 m, width 0.3 m. Columnar: pillars 0.3×0.3 m every 1.5-2 m. The volume of concrete for a house 6×8 m will be 2-4 m³ for strip or 1-2 m³ for columnar.

faqItems.q: How much cement is needed for a foundation?
faqItems.a: The amount of cement depends on the brand of concrete. M200: 280 kg/m³, M250: 330 kg/m³, M300: 380 kg/m³. Example: a foundation of 20 m³ of M200 concrete requires 20×280 = 5,600 kg of cement = 112 bags of 50 kg. Taking into account the 10% reserve, 123 bags are needed.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a barn?
faqItems.a: For a barn, a columnar or strip shallow foundation is usually used. Columnar: 4-6 pillars measuring 0.3×0.3 m, depth 0.5-0.7 m. The volume of concrete for a 4×3 m shed will be 0.5-1 m³. Use concrete grade M200.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation drainage?
faqItems.a: Drainage is calculated along the perimeter of the foundation. Drainage pipe length = foundation perimeter + 10% for turns. Pipe diameter 110 mm. The distance from the foundation is 0.5-1 m. The depth is 0.3-0.5 m below the base of the foundation. Example: perimeter 36 m → pipe 40 m.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for an extension?
faqItems.a: An extension usually uses the same type of foundation as the main house. The depth should be the same. Connection to the main foundation through an expansion joint. The volume of concrete is calculated similarly to the main foundation. Example: extension 4x6 m, strip foundation → volume 2-3 m³.

faqItems.q: How much does foundation formwork cost?
faqItems.a: The cost of formwork depends on the material and region. Wooden formwork: 500-800 ₽/m². Metal formwork (rent): 300-500 ₽/m² per month. For a foundation with a perimeter of 36 m and a height of 1.5 m, the formwork area is 108 m² → cost 54,000-86,400 ₽ (wooden) or rent 32,400-54,000 ₽/month.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a house made of timber?
faqItems.a: For a house made of timber, a shallow strip or columnar foundation is suitable. Strip: depth 0.7-1 m, width 0.3-0.4 m. Columnar: pillars 0.4×0.4 m every 1.5-2 m. The volume of concrete for a house 8×10 m will be 5-8 m³ for strip or 2-3 m³ for columnar.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a house made of aerated concrete?
faqItems.a: For a house made of aerated concrete, a strip foundation (depth 1.5-2 m) or a slab foundation (thickness 30-40 cm) is used. The width of the foundation should be 10 cm greater than the thickness of the wall. The volume of concrete for a 10x12 m house will be 20-30 m³ for strip concrete or 36-48 m³ for slab concrete. Concrete grade M250-M300.

faqItems.q: How much sand do you need for the foundation?
faqItems.a: Sand is needed for a cushion under the foundation (20-30 cm) and for concrete. Pillow: foundation area × 0.25 m. Concrete: volume of concrete × sand rate (730 kg/m³ for M200). Example: foundation 8×10 m, cushion 20 m³ sand, concrete 20 m³ → 20×730 = 14,600 kg sand for concrete. Total: 20 m³ + 14.6 t = 34.6 t sand.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a cottage?
faqItems.a: For a cottage, a deep strip or slab foundation is usually used. Tape: depth 1.5-2 m (below freezing), width 0.4-0.5 m. The volume of concrete for a cottage 12×15 m will be 30-40 m³. Concrete grade M250-M300. Reinforcement 12-16 mm, pitch 15-20 cm.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a summer house?
faqItems.a: A columnar or shallow strip foundation is suitable for a dacha. Columnar: pillars 0.3×0.3 m every 1.5-2 m, depth 0.8-1 m. Shallow strip: depth 0.5-0.7 m, width 0.3 m. The volume of concrete for a dacha 6×8 m will be 1-3 m³ depending on the type.

faqItems.q: Is reinforcement needed in a columnar foundation?
faqItems.a: Yes, reinforcement is also required in a columnar foundation. It ensures the strength of the pillars and prevents their destruction. Usually they use 4-6 rods with a diameter of 10-12 mm, connected with clamps. For a post 0.4×0.4×1.2 m you need 4.8-7.2 m of reinforcement (4-6 rods of 1.2 m each) plus clamps.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a bathhouse made of timber?
faqItems.a: For a bathhouse made of timber, a columnar or shallow strip foundation is used. Columnar: 6-9 pillars 0.4×0.4 m, depth 0.8-1 m. Belt: depth 0.6-0.8 m, width 0.3 m. The volume of concrete for a bathhouse 4×5 m will be 1-2 m³. Concrete grade M200.

faqItems.q: How much does it cost to pour the foundation yourself?
faqItems.a: When pouring it yourself, the cost of materials: concrete M200 20 m³ × 3500 ₽/m³ = 70,000 ₽. Reinforcement 2 t × 50,000 ₽/t = 100,000 ₽. Formwork (wood) 108 m² × 600 ₽/m² = 64,800 ₽. Sand, crushed stone: 30,000 ₽. Total: 264,800 ₽. Do-it-yourself work saves 150,000-200,000 rubles.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the foundation for a house on a slope?
faqItems.a: For a slope, a stepped strip foundation or a pile grillage is used. Calculate each step separately. Volume = the sum of the volumes of all stages. The fittings are calculated based on the total volume. Consider the need for drainage and slope strengthening. Example: 3 steps of 5 m³ = 15 m³ of concrete.

wallArea.title: Wall area calculator
wallArea.description: Calculation of wall area for finishing, taking into account openings and margin

tips.title: Useful tips
tips.measurements: Measure the dimensions of the room accurately, taking into account all protrusions and niches
tips.openings: Take into account all openings: windows, doors, arches for an accurate calculation
tips.reserve: Add 10-15% margin for losses and surface unevenness
tips.complex: For complex room shapes, break the room into simple geometric shapes

features.perimeterCalculation: Calculation of the perimeter of the room

seo.description: Free online wall area calculator. Calculate the wall area for finishing, taking into account windows, doors and stock. Determine exactly the amount of materials for painting, wallpaper, plaster.

overview.title: Wall area calculator
overview.content: An online wall area calculator will help you accurately calculate the wall area for finishing. Takes into account the size of the room, the height of the ceilings, the area of ​​windows and doors, as well as the margin for losses. Suitable for calculating the area for painting, wallpaper, plaster, tiles and other finishing materials.
overview.additionalContent: The wall area calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the perimeter and area of ​​all walls, taking into account openings. Calculation formula: Perimeter = 2 × (Length + Width), Total wall area = Perimeter × Height, Useful area = Total area - Opening area, Area with margin = Useful area × (1 + Stock / 100). For non-standard rooms, you can select the number of walls (2, 3 or 4).

calculationExamples.title: Examples of calculating wall area
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating wall area for various rooms:

example1.title: Example 1: Standard bedroom 4x5 m
example1.description: Rectangular bedroom with a ceiling height of 2.7 m, one window and one door
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 5 m
Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2.5 m²
Doors: 2 m²
Number of walls: 4
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (4 + 5) = 18 m
Total area: 18 × 2.7 = 48.6 m²
Openings: 2.5 + 2 = 4.5 m²
Usable area: 48.6 - 4.5 = 44.1 m²
Stock: 44.1 × 0.1 = 4.41 m²
Area with reserve: 44.1 + 4.41 = 48.51 m²
example1.note: For a standard bedroom, 48-50 m² of finishing material is usually required, taking into account the stock

example2.title: Example 2: Living room 6x8 m with large windows
example2.description: Spacious living room with panoramic windows, height 3 m
example2.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 8 m
Height: 3 m
Windows: 12 m² (panoramic glazing)
Doors: 3 m²
Number of walls: 4
Stock: 15%
example2.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (6 + 8) = 28 m
Total area: 28 × 3 = 84 m²
Openings: 12 + 3 = 15 m²
Usable area: 84 - 15 = 69 m²
Stock: 69 × 0.15 = 10.35 m²
Area with reserve: 69 + 10.35 = 79.35 m²
example2.note: Large windows significantly reduce wall area, requiring less finishing material

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3x4 m, corner room
example3.description: Corner kitchen with 3 walls, standard height
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 4 m
Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 m²
Doors: 0 m² (arch)
Number of walls: 3
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (3 + 4) = 14 m (approx.)
Total area: ~35 m² (for 3 walls)
Openings: 2 m²
Usable area: 35 - 2 = 33 m²
Stock: 33 × 0.1 = 3.3 m²
Area with reserve: 33 + 3.3 = 36.3 m²
example3.note: Corner rooms have fewer walls, which saves finishing materials

example4.title: Example 4: Bathroom 2.5x2 m
example4.description: Small bathroom with minimal openings
example4.input:
Length: 2.5 m, Width: 2 m
Height: 2.5 m
Windows: 0 m² (no windows)
Doors: 2 m²
Number of walls: 4
Stock: 15%
example4.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (2.5 + 2) = 9 m
Total area: 9 × 2.5 = 22.5 m²
Openings: 2 m²
Usable area: 22.5 - 2 = 20.5 m²
Reserve: 20.5 × 0.15 = 3.075 m²
Area with reserve: 20.5 + 3.075 = 23.575 m²
example4.note: For the bathroom, a 15% margin is recommended due to difficult conditions and the need for precise cutting of tiles

example5.title: Example 5: Long corridor 1.5×10 m
example5.description: Long corridor with two parallel walls
example5.input:
Length: 10 m, Width: 1.5 m
Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 0 m²
Doors: 5 m² (several doors)
Number of walls: 2
Stock: 10%
example5.calculation:
Perimeter: ~20 m (for 2 walls)
Total area: ~54 m²
Openings: 5 m²
Usable area: 54 - 5 = 49 m²
Stock: 49 × 0.1 = 4.9 m²
Area with reserve: 49 + 4.9 = 53.9 m²
example5.note: Corridors usually have only 2 walls (opposite), which simplifies the calculation

example6.title: Example 6: Office space 8x10 m
example6.description: Large office with many windows and doors, height 3 m
example6.input:
Length: 8 m, Width: 10 m
Height: 3 m
Windows: 20 m² (many windows)
Doors: 6 m²
Number of walls: 4
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (8 + 10) = 36 m
Total area: 36 × 3 = 108 m²
Openings: 20 + 6 = 26 m²
Usable area: 108 - 26 = 82 m²
Stock: 82 × 0.1 = 8.2 m²
Area with reserve: 82 + 8.2 = 90.2 m²
example6.note: Office premises usually have many openings, which significantly reduces the area for finishing

calculation.title: How is wall area calculated?
calculation.content: Calculating the wall area includes several stages to obtain an accurate result, taking into account all openings and margins.
calculation.usefulArea: Usable area = Total area - Window area - Door area
calculation.areaWithReserve: Area with reserve = Usable area × (1 + Reserve / 100)

advantages.title: Benefits of using a calculator
advantages.content: Using a wall area calculator provides many advantages when planning finishing work.

accuracy.title: Accuracy of calculations
accuracy.description: The calculator takes into account all parameters: room size, wall height, opening area. This guarantees an accurate calculation without overpayments or material shortages.

planning.title: Procurement planning
planning.description: Knowing the exact area of ​​the walls, you can plan the purchase of materials in advance and avoid downtime due to material shortages.

savings.title: Saving money
savings.description: Correct calculation allows you to buy the exact amount of materials without excess. Savings can amount to 10-15% of the cost of materials.

tips.title: Tips for calculating wall area
tips.content: To get an accurate result when calculating the wall area, follow our recommendations:

measurements.accurate: Measure the dimensions of the room accurately using a tape measure along the floor and walls
measurements.height: Measure the height of the walls in several places (may vary up to 5-10 cm)
measurements.multiple: For accuracy, take several measurements of each wall.

openings.all: Consider all openings: windows, doors, arches, niches
openings.measure: Measure the area of ​​openings accurately: width × height
openings.account: For panels and tiles, consider that openings can reduce waste

reserve.standard: For painting and wallpaper, a 10% reserve is enough
reserve.complex: For complex surfaces and patterns, add 15-20% margin
reserve.material: For tiles and panels, the margin depends on the size of the material and the installation method

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls to paint?
faqItems.a: Measure the length and width of the room, the height of the walls. Calculate the perimeter: 2 × (Length + Width). Multiply the perimeter by the height. Subtract the area of ​​windows and doors. Add 10% reserve. Example: room 4x5 m, height 2.7 m → perimeter 18 m, area 48.6 m², minus windows and doors 4.5 m² = 44.1 m², with a margin of 48.51 m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for wallpaper?
faqItems.a: The calculation is similar to painting: perimeter × height - openings + margin. For wallpaper, it is important to take into account the repeat (repetition of the pattern) and the method of sticking. Margin for wallpaper with a pattern: 15-20%, without a pattern: 10%. Measure the height from floor to ceiling in several places and use the maximum value.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for tiles?
faqItems.a: Calculation of area: perimeter × height - openings + margin. For tiles, the margin depends on the size of the tiles and the installation method: straight laying - 10%, diagonal - 15%, complex patterns - 20%. Consider trimming in corners and around openings. For the bathroom, a reserve of 15-20% is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls with windows and doors?
faqItems.a: Calculate the total area of ​​the walls: perimeter × height. Measure the area of ​​each window (width x height) and each door. Add up the areas of all openings. Subtract from total area. Formula: Usable area = (Perimeter × Height) - (Area of ​​all windows + Area of ​​all doors). Add a margin of 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls for plaster?
faqItems.a: The area of ​​walls for plaster is calculated in the same way: perimeter × height - openings + margin. For plaster, take into account the unevenness of the walls: for smooth walls the margin is 10%, for uneven walls - 15-20%. Include in the calculation the area of ​​the walls below the ceiling and above the floor (if leveling is required).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area in an irregularly shaped room?
faqItems.a: Break the room into simple geometric shapes (rectangles, triangles). Calculate the perimeter of each part. For corner rooms, use the "3 walls" option. For open spaces - “2 walls”. Add up the areas of all parts. Subtract openings and add headroom.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls for gluing panels?
faqItems.a: The calculation is similar to tiles: perimeter × height - openings + margin. For panels, consider their width and mounting method. Vertical panels: margin 10-15%. Horizontal panels with trimming: margin 15-20%. Consider trimming in corners and around openings.

faqItems.q: Do I need to take into account the ceiling area when calculating the walls?
faqItems.a: No, the ceiling area is calculated separately. Formula: Length × Width. But if the wall decoration extends to the ceiling (for example, wallpaper or panels), consider the transition zone. Usually this is 5-10 cm around the perimeter of the room.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls for decorative plaster?
faqItems.a: The area is calculated as standard: perimeter × height - openings + margin. For decorative plaster the margin is 10-15%. Consider the difficulty of application: textured coatings may require a larger margin (up to 20%) due to uneven application.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls to paint in the bathroom?
faqItems.a: For the bathroom, measure all the walls. Usually the bathroom has 4 walls, but it can be corner (3 walls). Calculate: perimeter × height - openings + margin 15-20%. There are often no windows in the bathroom, but there is a doorway. Use moisture-resistant paint and consider the difficulty of application.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing a kitchen?
faqItems.a: For the kitchen, consider the backsplash (the wall above the work surface) and common walls. Calculate the total area: perimeter × height. Subtract windows and doors. The apron usually has a height of 60-90 cm and is calculated separately. For the kitchen, the margin is 10-15% due to the complexity of the terrain.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​the corridor walls?
faqItems.a: The corridor usually has 2 parallel walls (long sides) or 4 walls (if closed). Measure the length and width of the corridor, height. Calculate the perimeter. If the corridor is open on one side, use the “2 walls” option. Consider all the doors in the hallway. Reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for a children's room?
faqItems.a: Standard calculation: perimeter × height - openings + margin. For a children's room, consider the safety of materials (environmentally friendly). Measure all walls, taking into account niches and projections. For bright wallpaper with a pattern, the margin is 15-20% due to the need to match the pattern.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for office decoration?
faqItems.a: For an office space, measure the length and width. Offices often have many windows and doors. Calculate: perimeter × height - all openings + 10% margin. Take into account partitions (walls between workstations), they are calculated separately. For standard office ceilings (2.5-3 m), use the maximum height.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls for turnkey painting?
faqItems.a: Turnkey means complete finishing of all walls. Measure all walls, including corridors and utility rooms. Calculate each room separately: perimeter × height - openings + margin. Add up all the squares. Turnkey painting margin: 10-15%. Consider the number of layers of paint (usually 2-3).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for wallpaper with rapport?
faqItems.a: The area of ​​the walls is calculated as standard: perimeter × height - openings. But for wallpaper with rapport, a larger margin is needed: 15-20% instead of 10%. Rapport is a repeating pattern. The greater the repeat, the more waste there is when sticking. Consider the fit of the pattern in the corners and at the joints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting a balcony?
faqItems.a: A balcony usually has 3 walls (two side and one front). Measure the dimensions of each wall separately. Add up the squares. Consider windows (usually large ones). The margin is 15-20% due to the difficulty of application on small surfaces and corners. Consider temperature conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing a bedroom?
faqItems.a: Standard bedroom 4x5 m: perimeter 18 m, height 2.7 m → area 48.6 m². Subtract window (2-3 m²) and door (2 m²) = 44-45 m² usable area. With a margin of 10%: 48-50 m² of material. For the bedroom, consider the comfort of materials and environmental friendliness.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for PVC panels?
faqItems.a: The calculation is similar to tiles: perimeter × height - openings + margin. For PVC panels, consider their length (usually 2.7 m or 3 m) and width (10-30 cm). The margin depends on the mounting method: horizontally - 15-20%, vertically - 10-15%. Consider trimming in corners.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for drywall?
faqItems.a: For drywall, calculate the area of ​​the frame (profiles). Wall area: perimeter × height. Keep in mind that the drywall is mounted on the frame, so take into account the pitch of the profiles (usually 40-60 cm). Area of ​​drywall sheets: walls + 10-15% margin for trimming.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls for painting the facade?
faqItems.a: For the facade, measure the perimeter of the building and the height of the walls. Take into account all openings (windows, doors, gates). The margin for facade painting is 15-20% due to difficult working conditions and the need for touch-up painting. Consider the number of layers (usually 2-3 for a facade).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​the walls for finishing the hallway?
faqItems.a: The hallway (corridor) often has 2 or 4 walls. Measure the length and width. If the hallway is open on one side, use “2 walls”. Calculate: perimeter × height - openings (usually only the door) + 10% margin. Consider the narrowness of the space and the need for careful trimming.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting a garage?
faqItems.a: A garage usually has 4 walls, but may have a gate (one wall is missing). Measure the dimensions of all walls. Consider the gate as an opening. Area: perimeter × height - openings + margin 10-15%. For the garage, use durable paint. Consider the operating conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls for liquid wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Liquid wallpaper is applied like plaster. Calculation: perimeter × height - openings + margin 15-20%. Liquid wallpaper requires a larger supply due to the characteristics of application and possible unevenness. Consider the consumption per 1 m² (usually indicated on the packaging) and the number of layers.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for decorating a store?
faqItems.a: For a store, measure all the walls of the sales area and utility rooms. Calculate each room separately: perimeter × height - openings + margin of 10-15%. Add up all the squares. Consider storefronts (large openings) and the need for a durable finish. The wear resistance of materials is important for the store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting a basement?
faqItems.a: The basement can have different configurations. Measure all walls. Consider humidity and the need for waterproofing. Area: perimeter × height - openings + margin 15-20%. For the basement, use special paints (anti-fungal, moisture-resistant). The height of the basement is usually lower than standard (2-2.5 m).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing the attic?
faqItems.a: The attic has a complex shape with sloping walls. Break up walls into simple shapes. For sloped walls, measure the average height or calculate the triangular sections separately. Area: the sum of all sections - openings + margin of 15-20%. Consider the difficulty of application on inclined surfaces.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting a pantry?
faqItems.a: The pantry is usually a small room. Standard calculation: perimeter × height - openings (usually only the door) + 10% margin. Consider the small size of the pantry and the need to conserve materials. For the pantry, you can use simpler finishing materials.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for restaurant decoration?
faqItems.a: For a restaurant, measure all rooms: hall, kitchen, utility rooms. Calculate each separately: perimeter × height - openings + margin 15%. For the hall, take into account the specific requirements (easy cleaning, fire safety). For the kitchen - moisture-resistant materials. Add up the areas of all rooms.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting a cafe?
faqItems.a: Similar to a restaurant: measure the hall and utility rooms. Perimeter × height - openings + 15% margin. For cafes, wear resistance and easy cleaning of surfaces are important. Consider the specifics of the room (high traffic, humidity). It is recommended to use washable paints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing a sauna?
faqItems.a: For a sauna, measure all the walls of the steam room. Consider high temperature and humidity. Area: perimeter × height - openings + margin 15-20%. Special materials are used for the sauna (wooden paneling, special paints). Consider the need for ventilation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting a loggia balcony?
faqItems.a: A loggia is different from a balcony: it is built into the building and has 3 walls (or 4 if closed). Measure all walls. Consider the windows. Area: perimeter × height - openings + margin 15-20%. For the loggia, use frost-resistant materials. Consider insulation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing a bath?
faqItems.a: For a bath, measure the steam room and washing room separately. Steam room: perimeter × height - openings + 20% margin. Washing room: perimeter × height - openings + margin 15-20%. Use moisture-resistant and heat-resistant materials (wooden paneling, special paints). Take into account difficult conditions (high humidity, temperature).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting a staircase?
faqItems.a: The staircase has a complex configuration. Measure the perimeter on each floor. Consider flights of stairs and landings. Area: perimeter × height - openings (windows, doors) + margin 15%. Wear resistance and easy cleaning are important for a staircase. Use washable paints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing a gym?
faqItems.a: For a gym, measure the perimeter of the large room. Typically, gyms have high ceilings (3-5 m). Area: perimeter × height - openings + margin 10-15%. Consider the requirements for materials (strength, wear resistance). Specialized coverings are used for the gym.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for painting an attic?
faqItems.a: The attic has a complex shape with sloping walls. Break it down into simple sections. For sloped walls, measure the average height. Area: the sum of all sections - openings + margin of 15-20%. Consider the difficulty of application on inclined surfaces. Simple materials are usually used for the attic.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing an industrial premises?
faqItems.a: For a manufacturing facility, measure a large perimeter. The height is usually higher than standard (3-6 m). Area: perimeter × height - openings (gates, windows) + margin 10-15%. Consider safety requirements (fire resistance, wear resistance). Use specialized industrial paints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the area of ​​walls to paint for wallpapering?
faqItems.a: Before wallpapering, the walls are usually primed and painted. Area: perimeter × height - openings + margin 10%. The primer is applied in 1-2 layers, paint for wallpaper - in 1 layer. Consider the consumption of primer and paint per m² (usually indicated on the packaging). The reserve is needed for high-quality surface preparation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the wall area for finishing a studio apartment?
faqItems.a: A studio is a large room without partitions. Measure the overall perimeter and height. Consider zoning (there may be partial division). Area: perimeter × height - openings + margin 10-15%. Consider the large area and the need for a uniform finish. Accent walls are often used for studios.

step1.name: Measure the dimensions of the room
step1.text: Measure the length and width of the room in meters, as well as the height of the walls

ventilation.title: Ventilation calculator
ventilation.description: Calculation of ventilation performance for premises

tips.title: Useful tips
tips.supply: Supply ventilation should provide a flow of fresh air
tips.exhaust: Exhaust ventilation removes polluted air from the room
tips.balance: The balance of supply and exhaust ventilation ensures normal air exchange
tips.consult: For complex objects, specialist consultation is recommended

seo.title: Ventilation calculator - Calculation of room ventilation | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online ventilation calculator. Calculate ventilation performance for residential, office and industrial premises. Takes into account the volume of the room, type, number of people.
seo.keywords: ventilation calculator, ventilation calculation, ventilation performance, air exchange rate, room ventilation calculation, apartment ventilation, house ventilation, supply ventilation, exhaust ventilation, mechanical ventilation, natural ventilation, air exchange calculation, fan performance, kitchen ventilation, bathroom ventilation, office ventilation, restaurant ventilation, gym ventilation, industrial premises ventilation, ventilation system, ventilation design, online ventilation calculation, air exchange calculator, ventilation volume, air exchange rate, indoor air exchange, calculation of bathroom ventilation, nursery ventilation, bedroom ventilation, living room ventilation

overview.title: Ventilation calculator
overview.content: An online ventilation calculator will help you calculate the required performance of the ventilation system for various types of premises. Takes into account the volume of the room, type (living room, kitchen, bathroom, office, etc.), number of people and air exchange rate. Suitable for calculating supply, exhaust and combined ventilation.
overview.additionalContent: The ventilation calculator uses standard air exchange rates for different types of premises according to building codes. Calculation formula: Room volume = Length × Width × Height, Volume capacity = Volume × Air exchange rate, People capacity = Number of people × Air rate per person, Required capacity = max (By volume, By people). For different types of premises, different air exchange rates apply.

calculationExamples.title: Examples of ventilation calculations
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating ventilation for various rooms:

example1.title: Example 1: Living room 4x5 m
example1.description: Standard size bedroom or living room, height 2.7 m
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 2.7 m
Type: Living room
Number of people: 2
Frequency: 1 time/hour (auto)
Rate per person: 30 m³/h (auto)
example1.calculation:
Volume: 4 × 5 × 2.7 = 54 m³
By volume: 54 × 1 = 54 m³/h
By people: 2 × 30 = 60 m³/h
Required: max(54, 60) = 60 m³/h
example1.note: For a living room, natural ventilation or a small-capacity supply and exhaust system is usually sufficient.

example2.title: Example 2: Kitchen 3x4 m with hood
example2.description: Standard size kitchen with gas stove, height 2.7 m
example2.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Type: Kitchen
Number of people: 1
Frequency: 3 times/hour (auto)
Rate per person: 60 m³/h (auto)
example2.calculation:
Volume: 3 × 4 × 2.7 = 32.4 m³
By volume: 32.4 × 3 = 97.2 m³/h
By people: 1 × 60 = 60 m³/h
Required: max(97.2, 60) = 97.2 m³/h
example2.note: For the kitchen, exhaust ventilation above the stove with a capacity of at least 90 m³/h is required

example3.title: Example 3: Bathroom 2x2 m
example3.description: Small bathroom, height 2.5 m
example3.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 2 m, Height: 2.5 m
Type: Bath/toilet
Number of people: 1
Frequency: 3 times/hour (auto)
Rate per person: 25 m³/h (car)
example3.calculation:
Volume: 2 × 2 × 2.5 = 10 m³
By volume: 10 × 3 = 30 m³/h
By people: 1 × 25 = 25 m³/h
Required: max(30, 25) = 30 m³/h
example3.note: The bathroom requires exhaust ventilation with a capacity of at least 25 m³/h

example4.title: Example 4: Office space 6x8 m
example4.description: Open office for 10 employees, height 3 m
example4.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 8 m, Height: 3 m
Type: Office
Number of people: 10
Frequency: 2 times/hour (auto)
Rate per person: 40 m³/h (auto)
example4.calculation:
Volume: 6 × 8 × 3 = 144 m³
By volume: 144 × 2 = 288 m³/h
By people: 10 × 40 = 400 m³/h
Required: max(288, 400) = 400 m³/h
example4.note: Office premises require mechanical supply and exhaust ventilation with air filtration

example5.title: Example 5: Restaurant hall 10x12 m
example5.description: Restaurant hall for 50 visitors, height 3.5 m
example5.input:
Length: 10 m, Width: 12 m, Height: 3.5 m
Type: Restaurant/cafe
Number of people: 50
Frequency: 5 times/hour (auto)
Rate per person: 60 m³/h (auto)
example5.calculation:
Volume: 10 × 12 × 3.5 = 420 m³
By volume: 420 × 5 = 2100 m³/h
By people: 50 × 60 = 3000 m³/h
Required: max(2100, 3000) = 3000 m³/h
example5.note: A restaurant requires powerful supply and exhaust ventilation to remove odors and excess heat

example6.title: Example 6: Gym 8x10 m
example6.description: Gym for training, height 4 m
example6.input:
Length: 8 m, Width: 10 m, Height: 4 m
Type: Gym
Number of people: 15
Frequency: 4 times/hour (auto)
Rate per person: 80 m³/h (auto)
example6.calculation:
Volume: 8 × 10 × 4 = 320 m³
By volume: 320 × 4 = 1280 m³/h
By people: 15 × 80 = 1200 m³/h
Required: max(1280, 1200) = 1280 m³/h
example6.note: The gym requires intensive ventilation to remove carbon dioxide and moisture, a capacity of at least 4 times/hour

calculation.title: How is ventilation calculated?
calculation.content: Ventilation calculation includes several stages to determine the required performance of the ventilation system.
calculation.capacityByVolume: Volume capacity = Volume × Air change rate
calculation.capacityByPeople: Productivity by people = Number of people × Air rate per person
calculation.requiredCapacity: Required capacity = max(By volume, By people)

advantages.title: Benefits of using a calculator
advantages.content: Using a ventilation calculator provides many benefits when designing ventilation systems.

health.title: Health and comfort
health.description: Properly calculated ventilation provides clean air, removes dirt and moisture, and creates comfortable conditions for people.

efficiency.title: Energy efficiency
efficiency.description: Accurate calculation allows you to select the optimal ventilation performance, which reduces energy consumption and operating costs.

comfort.title: Comfortable microclimate
comfort.description: Adequate ventilation maintains optimal temperature, humidity and indoor air quality.

tips.title: Ventilation tips
tips.content: To ensure efficient operation of the ventilation system, follow our recommendations:

system.natural: Natural ventilation is suitable for small living spaces with low pollution
system.mechanical: Mechanical ventilation is necessary for offices, restaurants, industrial premises
system.combined: Combined system combines natural and mechanical ventilation

installation.ducts: Air ducts must be of minimal length and with minimal bends
installation.location: Place supply grilles in residential areas, exhaust grilles in contaminated areas
installation.noise: Use silencers to reduce noise levels from mechanical ventilation

maintenance.cleaning: Regularly clean air ducts and grilles of dust and dirt.
maintenance.filters: Replace filters in the supply ventilation at least once every 3-6 months
maintenance.check: Check the operation of fans and dampers at least once a year

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for an apartment?
faqItems.a: Calculate ventilation for each room separately: bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom. For living rooms, the frequency is 1 time/hour, for the kitchen 3 times/hour, for the bathroom 3 times/hour. Sum up the performance of all rooms. Example: apartment 60 m², height 2.7 m → total volume 162 m³, required productivity ~200 m³/h for the entire apartment.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation performance?
faqItems.a: Productivity = Room volume × Air change rate or Number of people × Norm per person. The maximum value is taken. Example: room 4×5×2.7 m = 54 m³, frequency 1 time/hour → productivity 54 m³/hour. If there are 2 people in the room, 30 m³/h → 60 m³/h, take 60 m³/h.

faqItems.q: What is the air exchange rate for the kitchen?
faqItems.a: For the kitchen, the air exchange rate is 3 times/hour for general ventilation and an additional hood above the stove with a capacity of at least 90 m³/h (for a gas stove) or 60 m³/h (for an electric one) is required. The hood operates independently of general ventilation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for an office?
faqItems.a: For an office, the air exchange rate is 2 times/hour, the air norm per person is 40 m³/hour. Calculate: office volume × 2 or number of employees × 40, take the maximum value. For an office for 20 people with an area of ​​100 m², height 3 m → volume 300 m³, volume 600 m³/h, people 800 m³/h, required 800 m³/h.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a bathroom?
faqItems.a: For the bathroom, the frequency is 3 times/hour, the norm per person is 25 m³/hour. Bathroom 2×2×2.5 m = 10 m³, capacity 10×3 = 30 m³/h. Exhaust ventilation is required, supply ventilation is not necessary (air comes from other rooms). An exhaust fan with a timer is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate natural ventilation?
faqItems.a: Natural ventilation works due to differences in temperature and pressure. Performance calculations are complex and depend on many factors. Typically, natural ventilation provides 0.5-1 times/hour of air exchange. For an accurate calculation, take into account the area of ​​the ventilation ducts, temperature differences, and wind direction.

faqItems.q: How to calculate mechanical ventilation?
faqItems.a: Mechanical ventilation is calculated as volume × rate or people × rate. The fan performance must correspond to the calculated one. Example: room 50 m³, frequency 3 times/h → a fan with a capacity of 150 m³/h is needed. Take into account losses in air ducts (10-20%), add a reserve.

faqItems.q: How to calculate supply and exhaust ventilation?
faqItems.a: Supply and exhaust ventilation must be balanced: supply ≈ exhaust. Calculate the required capacity. Supply ventilation: 100% of required. Exhaust: 90-100% of the supply. Example: 100 m³/h required → supply 100 m³/h, exhaust 90-100 m³/h. A slight imbalance (5-10%) is allowed to prevent drafts.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a restaurant?
faqItems.a: For a restaurant, the frequency is 5 times/hour, the norm per person is 60 m³/hour. Hall 10×12×3.5 m = 420 m³, volume 420×5 = 2100 m³/h. With 50 visitors: 50×60 = 3000 m³/h. Required: 3000 m³/h. Powerful supply and exhaust ventilation is required to remove odors from the kitchen and living room, and additionally an exhaust hood above the kitchen equipment.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a gym?
faqItems.a: For the gym, the frequency is 4 times/hour, the norm per person is 80 m³/hour. Gym 8×10×4 m = 320 m³, volume 320×4 = 1280 m³/h. With 15 trainees: 15×80 = 1200 m³/h. Required: 1280 m³/h. Intensive ventilation is necessary to remove carbon dioxide, moisture and excess heat. A mechanical supply and exhaust system is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a production facility?
faqItems.a: For industrial premises, the frequency is 3-6 times/hour, depending on the type of production and harmfulness. Calculate by volume and add removal of local hazards. Example: workshop 20×15×4 m = 1200 m³, multiplicity 4 times/h → 4800 m³/h. Consider local suction from equipment. For hazardous industries, the frequency can be up to 10-20 times/hour.

faqItems.q: How to calculate air exchange in a room?
faqItems.a: Air exchange = Ventilation capacity / Room volume. Example: capacity 100 m³/h, volume 50 m³ → air exchange 100/50 = 2 times/h. The air exchange rate shows how many times per hour the air in the room is completely replaced. The norm for living rooms: 1 time/hour, for the kitchen: 3 times/hour, for the bathroom: 3 times/hour.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fan performance?
faqItems.a: The fan performance must correspond to the required ventilation performance, taking into account losses in the air ducts. Required performance × (1 + losses). Losses in air ducts are usually 10-20%. Example: 100 m³/h required, 15% loss → fan should be 100×1.15 = 115 m³/h. Choose a fan with a performance slightly higher than the calculated one.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a children's room?
faqItems.a: For a children's room, the frequency is 1 time/hour, the norm for a child is 30 m³/hour. Children's room 3×4×2.7 m = 32.4 m³, productivity 32.4×1 = 32.4 m³/h. For one child: 1×30 = 30 m³/h. Required: 32.4 m³/h. Supply and exhaust ventilation with filtration is recommended to ensure clean air.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a bedroom?
faqItems.a: For a bedroom, the frequency is 1 time/hour, the norm per person is 30 m³/hour. Bedroom 4×5×2.7 m = 54 m³, productivity 54×1 = 54 m³/h. For two people: 2×30 = 60 m³/h. Required: 60 m³/h. For the bedroom, natural ventilation or a quiet mechanical supply and exhaust system is sufficient. Quiet fan operation is important.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a living room?
faqItems.a: For the living room, the frequency is 1 time/hour, the norm per person is 30 m³/hour. Living room 6×8×2.7 m = 129.6 m³, productivity 130×1 = 130 m³/h. For 4-5 people: 5×30 = 150 m³/h. Required: 150 m³/h. For a large living room, mechanical ventilation is recommended to ensure a comfortable microclimate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a kitchen with a gas stove?
faqItems.a: For a kitchen with a gas stove, an exhaust hood with a capacity of at least 90 m³/h above the stove is required. General kitchen ventilation: volume × 3 times/hour. Example: kitchen 3×4×2.7 m = 32.4 m³, total ventilation 32.4×3 = 97.2 m³/h, hood above the stove 90 m³/h. The hood works independently and turns on when cooking.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a kitchen with an electric stove?
faqItems.a: For a kitchen with an electric stove, the hood must have a capacity of at least 60 m³/h. General ventilation: volume × 3 times/hour. Kitchen 3×4×2.7 m = 32.4 m³, total ventilation 97.2 m³/h, exhaust 60 m³/h. An electric stove emits fewer harmful substances, so the hood may be of lower power.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a bathroom?
faqItems.a: For a bathroom (bathtub + toilet) the frequency is 3 times/hour, the norm per person is 25 m³/hour. Bathroom 2×2×2.5 m = 10 m³, capacity 10×3 = 30 m³/h. Exhaust ventilation is required; supply ventilation is not required (air comes from other rooms through the cracks under the door). An exhaust fan with a humidity sensor is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for an office building?
faqItems.a: For an office building, each room is calculated separately, then summed up. Office: frequency 2 times/hour, norm 40 m³/hour per person. A multi-storey office building requires a centralized supply and exhaust system with heat recovery. Central system capacity = sum of all rooms. Consider losses in main air ducts.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a store?
faqItems.a: For a store, the frequency depends on the type: food 2-3 times/hour, non-food 1-2 times/hour. The norm per visitor is 40-60 m³/h depending on the area. Trading area 100 m², height 3 m = 300 m³, multiplicity 2 times/hour → 600 m³/hour. With 30 visitors: 30×50 = 1500 m³/h. Required: 1500 m³/h. Supply and exhaust ventilation with recovery is required.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a warehouse?
faqItems.a: For a warehouse, the frequency is 1 time/hour for ordinary warehouses, 2-3 times/hour for warehouses with chemicals. Warehouse 20×30×5 m = 3000 m³, frequency 1 time/hour → 3000 m³/hour. For ordinary warehouses, natural ventilation through gates and windows is sufficient. Warehouses containing hazardous substances require mechanical supply and exhaust ventilation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a cafe?
faqItems.a: For a cafe, the frequency is 5 times/hour, the norm per visitor is 60 m³/hour. Cafe hall 8×10×3 m = 240 m³, volume 240×5 = 1200 m³/h. With 30 visitors: 30×60 = 1800 m³/h. Required: 1800 m³/h. Powerful supply and exhaust ventilation is required to remove odors and excess heat. Additionally, there is a hood above the kitchen equipment.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a sauna?
faqItems.a: For a sauna, the frequency is 5-10 times/hour for the steam room, 3-5 times/hour for the dressing room. Steam room 2×2×2.2 m = 8.8 m³, multiplicity 7 times/hour → 61.6 m³/hour. Exhaust ventilation is required to remove moisture and carbon dioxide. Supply ventilation should supply a small amount of air (10-20% of the exhaust) to prevent drafts.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a bathhouse?
faqItems.a: For a steam bath: frequency 5-10 times/hour, washing: 3-5 times/hour. Steam room 3×4×2.2 m = 26.4 m³, multiplicity 7 times/h → 185 m³/h. Washing room 3×3×2.5 m = 22.5 m³, multiplicity 4 times/h → 90 m³/h. Powerful exhaust ventilation is required to remove moisture. Use fans with moisture protection (IP65).

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a swimming pool?
faqItems.a: For a swimming pool, the frequency is 3-5 times/hour, the norm is 80 m³/hour per visitor. Pool 10×20×3 m = 600 m³, multiplicity 4 times/hour → 2400 m³/hour. With 10 visitors: 10×80 = 800 m³/h. Required: 2400 m³/h. Supply and exhaust ventilation with air dehumidification is required to remove excess moisture. Specialized equipment for swimming pools is used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a production workshop?
faqItems.a: For a production workshop, the frequency is 3-10 times/hour, depending on the harmfulness of production. Workshop 30×20×6 m = 3600 m³, multiplicity 4 times/hour → 14400 m³/hour. For hazardous industries, the frequency can be up to 20 times/hour. Consider local suction from equipment. The design of specialized ventilation systems is required.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a laboratory?
faqItems.a: For a laboratory, the frequency is 4-6 times/hour, the norm is 40-60 m³/hour per worker. Laboratory 5×6×2.8 m = 84 m³, multiplicity 5 times/h → 420 m³/h. With 3 workers: 3×50 = 150 m³/h. Required: 420 m³/h. Supply and exhaust ventilation with filtration and local suction from fume hoods are required. The air should not be recirculated.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a classroom?
faqItems.a: For a classroom, the frequency is 2 times/hour, the norm is 40 m³/hour per student. Class 8×6×3 m = 144 m³, multiplicity 2 times/h → 288 m³/h. With 25 students: 25×40 = 1000 m³/h. Required: 1000 m³/h. Mechanical supply and exhaust ventilation is required to provide fresh air and comfortable learning conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a cinema hall?
faqItems.a: For a cinema hall, the frequency is 4-5 times/hour, the norm is 40 m³/hour per viewer. Hall 15×20×4 m = 1200 m³, multiplicity 4 times/hour → 4800 m³/hour. With 100 spectators: 100×40 = 4000 m³/h. Required: 4800 m³/h. Powerful supply and exhaust ventilation is required to remove carbon dioxide, moisture and ensure the comfort of spectators.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a basement?
faqItems.a: For the basement, the frequency is 1-2 times/hour, depending on the purpose. Basement 10×8×2.5 m = 200 m³, frequency 1.5 times/h → 300 m³/h. Exhaust ventilation is important for the basement to remove moisture and prevent dampness. Supply ventilation can be natural through special channels.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for an attic?
faqItems.a: For the attic, the frequency is 0.5-1 times/hour. The attic is usually ventilated naturally through dormers and vents. The volume of the attic is large, so even a small multiplicity gives greater productivity. Attic 15×10×3 m = 450 m³, frequency 0.5 times/h → 225 m³/h. It is important to provide a draft to remove moisture.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a garage?
faqItems.a: For the garage, the frequency is 2-4 times/hour, depending on use. Garage 6×4×2.5 m = 60 m³, multiplicity 3 times/h → 180 m³/h. For a garage with the engine running, the frequency must be at least 4 times/hour. Exhaust ventilation is required to remove exhaust gases. Supply ventilation is natural through the gate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a laundry room?
faqItems.a: For laundry, frequency 5-7 times/hour to remove moisture. Laundry 4×5×2.8 m = 56 m³, frequency 6 times/hour → 336 m³/hour. Powerful exhaust ventilation is required to remove excess moisture. Supply ventilation should supply heated air to prevent condensation. Fans with moisture protection are used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a server room?
faqItems.a: For a server, the frequency is 3-5 times/hour, the norm is 80-100 m³/hour per 1 kW of equipment. Server room 4×5×3 m = 60 m³, multiplicity 4 times/h → 240 m³/h. With 10 kW equipment: 10×90 = 900 m³/h. Required: 900 m³/h. Supply and exhaust ventilation with air conditioning is required to remove excess heat from the servers.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for a boiler room?
faqItems.a: For a boiler room, the frequency is 3 times/hour, additional combustion air is required (for gas boilers 1 m³ of air per 1 kW of power). Boiler room 5×4×3 m = 60 m³, frequency 3 times/h → 180 m³/h. A 24 kW boiler requires an additional 24 m³/h of combustion air. Required: 204 m³/h. Supply ventilation is required to supply combustion air.

overview.title: Online tile calculator
overview.content: An online tile calculator will help you calculate the required amount of tiles for laying floors or walls. The dimensions of the room, the dimensions of the tiles, the width of the seam between the tiles and the margin for trimming and possible defects are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The tile calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the amount of material based on surface type, installation method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various types of tiles: ceramic, porcelain stoneware, mosaic, vinyl. Calculation formula: Total number of tiles = (Room area / Area of ​​one tile) × (1 + Stock / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Tile calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the number of tiles for various rooms and types of tiles:

example1.title: Example 1: Bathroom 3x2 meters
example1.description: Standard bathroom with ceramic tiles 30x30 cm
example1.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2 m
Tiles: 30×30 cm
Package: 10 pcs
Stock: 10%
Seam width: 2 mm
example1.calculation:
Room area: 3 × 2 = 6 m²
Tile area: 0.3 × 0.3 = 0.09 m²
Number of tiles: 6 / 0.09 = 66.7 ≈ 67 pcs
With a margin: 67 × 1.1 = 73.7 ≈ 74 pcs.
Packs: 74 / 10 = 7.4 ≈ 8 packs
example1.note: Standard bathroom, it is recommended to take 8-9 packages with a small margin

example2.title: Example 2: Kitchen 4x3 meters
example2.description: Kitchen with porcelain stoneware 60×60 cm
example2.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m
Tiles: 60×60 cm
Package: 4 pcs
Stock: 10%
Seam width: 3 mm
example2.calculation:
Room area: 4 × 3 = 12 m²
Tile area: 0.6 × 0.6 = 0.36 m²
Number of tiles: 12 / 0.36 = 33.3 ≈ 34 pcs
With a margin: 34 × 1.1 = 37.4 ≈ 38 pcs
Packs: 38 / 4 = 9.5 ≈ 10 packs
example2.note: For the kitchen it is better to choose moisture-resistant porcelain tiles and increase the margin to 15%

example3.title: Example 3: Hallway 2×1.5 meters
example3.description: Small hallway with tiles 20×30 cm
example3.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m
Tiles: 20×30 cm
Packaging: 15 pcs.
Stock: 10%
Seam width: 2 mm
example3.calculation:
Room area: 2 × 1.5 = 3 m²
Tile area: 0.2 × 0.3 = 0.06 m²
Number of tiles: 3 / 0.06 = 50 pcs
With reserve: 50 × 1.1 = 55 pcs.
Packs: 55 / 15 = 3.7 ≈ 4 packs
example3.note: Wear-resistant tiles are recommended for the hallway

example4.title: Example 4: Kitchen apron 3×0.6 meters
example4.description: Apron over the work surface with mosaic 10x10 cm
example4.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 0.6 m
Tiles: 10×10 cm
Packaging: 100 pcs
Stock: 15%
Seam width: 2 mm
example4.calculation:
Room area: 3 × 0.6 = 1.8 m²
Tile area: 0.1 × 0.1 = 0.01 m²
Number of tiles: 1.8 / 0.01 = 180 pcs
With reserve: 180 × 1.15 = 207 pcs.
Packs: 207 / 100 = 2.07 ≈ 3 packs
example4.note: Glass or ceramic mosaic is recommended for the apron

example5.title: Example 5: The floor in the living room is 5x4 meters
example5.description: Large living room with large format tiles 80x80 cm
example5.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m
Tiles: 80×80 cm
Package: 2 pcs
Stock: 10%
Seam width: 3 mm
example5.calculation:
Room area: 5 × 4 = 20 m²
Tile area: 0.8 × 0.8 = 0.64 m²
Number of tiles: 20 / 0.64 = 31.25 ≈ 32 pcs
With a margin: 32 × 1.1 = 35.2 ≈ 36 pcs
Packs: 36 / 2 = 18 packs
example5.note: For large rooms it is better to use large-format tiles to visually expand the space

example6.title: Example 6: Bathroom with niches
example6.description: Bathroom with niches for shelves, tiles 25x40 cm
example6.input:
Length: 3.5 m, Width: 2.5 m
Niche area: 2 m²
Tiles: 25×40 cm
Package: 12 pcs
Stock: 15%
Seam width: 2 mm
example6.calculation:
Room area: 3.5 × 2.5 = 8.75 m²
Usable area: 8.75 - 2 = 6.75 m²
Tile area: 0.25 × 0.4 = 0.1 m²
Number of tiles: 6.75 / 0.1 = 67.5 ≈ 68 pcs
With a margin: 68 × 1.15 = 78.2 ≈ 79 pcs
Packs: 79 / 12 = 6.6 ≈ 7 packs
example6.note: If there are niches and corners, it is recommended to increase the margin to 15%
