calculation.title: How are pipe parameters calculated?
calculation.content: The calculation is based on the laws of hydraulics and includes:
calculation.diameter: Determination of diameter by flow and speed
calculation.pressure: Determination of pressure loss in a pipeline

methods.title: Calculation methods
methods.reynolds: Reynolds number to determine the flow regime
methods.moody: Moody diagram for coefficient of friction

parameters.title: Basic parameters
parameters.flowRate: Water flow (Q) - the volume of liquid passing through a section per unit time
parameters.velocity: Flow velocity (V) - the average speed of fluid movement in the pipe
parameters.diameter: Pipe diameter (D) - internal diameter of the pipeline
parameters.length: Pipe length (L) - total length of the pipeline section
parameters.pressure: Pressure (P) - static pressure in the system
parameters.density: Liquid density (ρ) - mass per unit volume
parameters.viscosity: Viscosity (μ) - the resistance of a liquid to flow
parameters.roughness: Roughness (ε) - the height of the roughness of the inner surface

regimes.title: Flow regimes
regimes.laminar: Laminar mode (Re < 2300) - smooth flow without vortices
regimes.turbulent: Turbulent mode (Re > 4000) - vortex flow with mixing

diameterCalculation.title: Pipe diameter calculation
diameterCalculation.description: The diameter is determined by the formula: D = √(4Q/πV), where Q is water flow (m³/s), V is flow velocity (m/s)
diameterCalculation.example: Example: At a flow rate of 0.1 m³/s and a speed of 2 m/s: D = √(4×0.1/π×2) = √(0.4/6.28) = √0.064 = 0.25 m = 250 mm

flowCalculation.title: Calculation of water consumption
flowCalculation.description: Flow is calculated as the product of cross-sectional area and flow velocity
flowCalculation.example: Example: For a pipe with a diameter of 200 mm at a speed of 1.5 m/s: Q = π×0.2²×1.5/4 = 0.047 m³/s = 47 l/s

pressureCalculation.title: Calculation of pressure loss
pressureCalculation.description: Pressure loss according to the Darcy-Weisbach formula taking into account the friction coefficient λ
pressureCalculation.example: Example: For a pipe with a length of 100 m, a diameter of 150 mm, a speed of 2 m/s: ΔP = 0.02 × (100/0.15) × (1000×2²/2) = 0.02 × 667 × 2000 = 26.680 Pa = 0.27 bar

reynoldsNumber.title: Reynolds number
reynoldsNumber.description: Determines the flow mode: laminar (Re < 2300) or turbulent (Re > 4000)
reynoldsNumber.example: Example: At a density of 1000 kg/m³, speed 2 m/s, diameter 0.2 m, viscosity 0.001 Pa s: Re = 1000×2×0.2/0.001 = 400,000 (turbulent mode)

features.title: Basic functions
features.diameterCalculationDesc: Determining the optimal diameter for a given flow rate
features.pressureCalculationDesc: Determination of pressure loss in the system
features.materialSupportDesc: Calculation taking into account the properties of various materials
features.exportDesc: Saving calculations in PDF and CSV formats

advantages.title: Benefits of the calculator
advantages.content: Our water pipe calculator provides many benefits:

accuracy.title: Accuracy of calculations
accuracy.description: The calculator uses proven hydraulic formulas and takes into account all factors: diameter, flow, speed, material, roughness and flow conditions for the most accurate results.

savings.title: Saving money
savings.description: Correct calculation of the diameter helps to choose the optimal pipe and avoid waste of materials, which significantly reduces the cost of the project.

planning.title: Project planning
planning.description: Knowing in advance the required diameter and pressure loss, you will be able to correctly design the system, avoiding installation errors.

convenience.title: Ease of use
convenience.description: A simple interface and quick calculations allow you to get all the necessary data in a few seconds without complex calculations and formulas.

tips.title: Tips for choosing and calculating water pipes
tips.content: To correctly select and calculate water pipes, it is important to take into account many factors that affect the operation of the system.

installation.title: Selection and installation
installation.diameter: Always choose a diameter with a margin of 10-15% of the calculated value to compensate for losses and future increases in load
installation.material: Consider the operating conditions: plastic pipes are suitable for cold water, metal-plastic or copper for hot water, steel for high pressures
installation.connections: When designing, take into account local resistances (fittings, valves, taps) - they increase pressure loss by 20-30%

calculation.title: Calculation of parameters
calculation.velocity: Optimal flow speed for water supply: 1.5-2.5 m/s. Lower speeds lead to stagnation, higher speeds lead to increased losses
calculation.pressure: Check the pressure loss - it should not exceed 0.2-0.3 bar per 100 m of length for normal operation of the system
calculation.reynolds: Determine the flow regime by the Reynolds number - for the turbulent regime (Re > 4000) the losses are higher, but the flow is more stable

optimization.title: System optimization
optimization.roughness: Plastic pipes have lower roughness and pressure loss than steel pipes - use them where possible
optimization.length: Minimize the length of the pipeline and the number of turns - each turn increases losses by 5-10%
optimization.temperature: Consider the water temperature - hot water has lower viscosity and lower pressure loss

faqItems.q: How to choose the diameter of a pipe for a water supply?
faqItems.a: The pipe diameter is selected based on the required water flow, permissible flow rate and pressure loss. For residential buildings, pipes with a diameter of 15-25 mm are usually used, for industrial facilities - up to 200 mm or more. Use the formula D = √(4Q/πV), where Q is flow (m³/s), V is speed (m/s).

faqItems.q: What factors affect pipe capacity?
faqItems.a: The throughput capacity depends on the pipe diameter, material, internal surface roughness, fluid viscosity, temperature and flow regime (laminar or turbulent). The larger the diameter and the lower the roughness, the higher the throughput.

faqItems.q: How to calculate pressure loss in a pipeline?
faqItems.a: Pressure loss is calculated using the Darcy-Weisbach formula: ΔP = λ × (L/D) × (ρV²/2), where λ is the friction coefficient, L is the pipe length, D is the diameter, ρ is the density, V is the speed. Local resistances (fittings, fittings) are also taken into account, which increase losses by 20-30%.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between laminar and turbulent regimes?
faqItems.a: Laminar mode (Re < 2300) is characterized by smooth fluid flow with low energy losses. Turbulent mode (Re > 4000) occurs at high speeds and is characterized by vortex motion with increased pressure losses, but a more stable flow.

faqItems.q: What pipe material is best for plumbing?
faqItems.a: The choice of material depends on the operating conditions. Plastic pipes (PVC, PPR) are suitable for cold water and have low pressure losses. Metal-plastic - for hot water, copper pipes - for heating systems, steel - for high pressures and industrial systems.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water flow by pipe diameter?
faqItems.a: The flow rate is calculated using the formula: Q = A × V = πD²V/4, where A is the cross-sectional area, V is the flow velocity, D is the pipe diameter. For example, for a pipe with a diameter of 100 mm at a speed of 2 m/s: Q = π×0.1²×2/4 = 0.0157 m³/s = 15.7 l/s.

faqItems.q: What is the optimal flow rate for water pipes?
faqItems.a: The optimal flow speed for water supply is 1.5-2.5 m/s. A speed of less than 1 m/s can lead to stagnation and sedimentation; a speed of more than 3 m/s increases pressure loss and noise in the system.

faqItems.q: How does pipe roughness affect pressure loss?
faqItems.a: The roughness of the inner surface of the pipe directly affects the coefficient of friction and pressure loss. Plastic pipes have a roughness of 0.0015-0.007 mm, steel - 0.03-0.05 mm, cast iron - 0.1-0.3 mm. The higher the roughness, the greater the pressure loss.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the Reynolds number for a water pipe?
faqItems.a: The Reynolds number is calculated by the formula: Re = ρVD/μ, where ρ is the density of the liquid (1000 kg/m³ for water), V is the flow velocity (m/s), D is the pipe diameter (m), μ is the dynamic viscosity (0.001 Pa s for water). Re < 2300 - laminar mode, Re > 4000 - turbulent.

faqItems.q: What pressure losses are permissible in a water supply?
faqItems.a: The permissible pressure loss in the water supply system should not exceed 0.2-0.3 bar per 100 m of length for normal operation of the system. For systems with a pump, losses may be higher, but should not exceed 0.5 bar per 100 m.

faqItems.q: How to choose a pipe diameter for a multi-story building?
faqItems.a: For a multi-storey building, the diameter is selected based on the total consumption of all apartments. Typically, pipes with a diameter of 50-100 mm are used for the riser, and 100-200 mm for the main line. The calculation is carried out taking into account peak flow and flow speed of 2-2.5 m/s.

faqItems.q: Does water temperature affect the calculation of plumbing?
faqItems.a: Yes, water temperature affects the viscosity and density of the liquid. Hot water (80-90°C) has a lower viscosity (0.0003 Pa s) and lower pressure loss by 15-20% compared to cold water (20°C). For heating systems this is important to consider.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the coefficient of friction for a pipe?
faqItems.a: The friction coefficient depends on the flow regime. For laminar flow: λ = 64/Re. For turbulent flow, the Blasius formula is used: λ = 0.316/Re^0.25 or the Colebrook-White formula to take into account roughness: 1/√λ = -2log(ε/(3.7D) + 2.51/(Re√λ)).

faqItems.q: What local resistances should be taken into account when calculating?
faqItems.a: Local resistances include fittings (bends, tees), valves, taps, gate valves, filters. Each element increases pressure loss by 5-15% of the dynamic pressure. For accurate calculations, local resistance coefficients ξ are used.

faqItems.q: What pipe diameter is needed for the heating system?
faqItems.a: For a heating system, the diameter is selected based on the thermal load and temperature difference. Typically, pipes with a diameter of 20-40 mm are used for a private house, and 50-150 mm for a multi-story house. It is important to take into account the lower viscosity of hot water.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the required pump pressure for a water supply system?
faqItems.a: The required pump pressure is calculated as the sum of the geometric lift height, pressure loss in the pipeline and local resistance, plus a margin of 10-15%. H = Hgeom + ΔP/ρg + Nlocal + Nreserve. For a residential building, a head of 30-50 m is usually required.

faqItems.q: Can plastic pipes be used for hot water?
faqItems.a: Yes, but it is important to choose the right type of plastic. Polypropylene pipes (PPR) with reinforcement are suitable for hot water up to 95°C. Polyethylene (PE) and PVC pipes are not suitable for hot water - they deform at temperatures above 60°C.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the diameter of a water pipe for a private house?
faqItems.a: For a private house, the diameter is calculated based on the number of water points and peak flow. Typically, pipes with a diameter of 15-25 mm are used for branches and 25-32 mm for the main. At a flow rate of 0.05 m³/s (50 l/s) and a speed of 2 m/s, a diameter of about 180 mm is required for the line.

faqItems.q: What formulas are used to calculate the water supply?
faqItems.a: Basic formulas: continuity equation Q = A×V, Darcy-Weisbach formula for pressure loss, Reynolds number Re = ρVD/μ, Hazen-Williams formula for quick calculations: V = 0.849C×R^0.63×S^0.54, where C is the roughness coefficient.

faqItems.q: How to take into account the margin when choosing a pipe diameter?
faqItems.a: It is recommended to choose a diameter with a margin of 10-15% of the calculated value. This compensates for losses in fittings, possible blockages, future increases in load and ensures stable operation of the system under non-standard operating conditions.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between the inner and outer diameter of a pipe?
faqItems.a: Internal diameter (Din) is the diameter of the pipe flow section, used for hydraulic calculations. Outer diameter (Dout) - the external size of the pipe, takes into account the wall thickness. For calculations, the internal diameter is always used: Din = Dout - 2×S, where S is the wall thickness.

faqItems.q: How to calculate pressure loss in a system with several branches?
faqItems.a: In a system with parallel branches, the pressure loss in each branch is the same, but the flow is distributed proportionally to the resistance. For successive sections, losses are summed up. Use the equivalent length principle or cost balancing method.

faqItems.q: What standard diameters of water pipes exist?
faqItems.a: Standard diameters of water pipes: 15, 20, 25, 32, 40, 50, 63, 75, 90, 110, 125, 140, 160, 200, 250, 315, 400 mm. For steel pipes: 15, 20, 25, 32, 40, 50, 65, 80, 100, 125, 150, 200 mm. The diameter is selected depending on the flow rate and flow rate.

faqItems.q: How does pipeline length affect pressure loss?
faqItems.a: Pressure loss is proportional to the length of the pipeline according to the Darcy-Weisbach formula. For every 100 m of length under standard conditions, 0.1-0.3 bar of loss is added. Therefore, it is important to minimize the length of the pipeline and use straight sections without bends.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a water supply system?
faqItems.a: The flow rate is calculated as the sum of the flow rates of all water withdrawal points, taking into account the simultaneity factor. For residential buildings, the simultaneity coefficient is 0.6-0.8. Consumption of one point: faucet - 0.2 l/s, toilet - 0.1 l/s, shower - 0.15 l/s, washing machine - 0.3 l/s.

faqItems.q: What are the pressure losses in steel pipes compared to plastic ones?
faqItems.a: Steel pipes have pressure losses 30-50% higher than plastic pipes due to greater roughness (0.045 mm versus 0.0015 mm). Under the same conditions, a plastic pipe with a diameter of 100 mm has a loss of 0.14 bar, a steel pipe - 0.2 bar per 100 m of length.

faqItems.q: How to choose the diameter of a pipe for a well?
faqItems.a: For a well, the diameter is selected based on the well's flow rate and the required flow rate. Typically, pipes with a diameter of 25-50 mm are used for private wells and 100-200 mm for industrial ones. It is important to take into account the losses in the suction pipe and the required pump pressure.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the hydraulic slope for a water pipeline?
faqItems.a: The hydraulic slope is calculated as the ratio of pressure loss to the length of the pipeline: i = ΔH/L = (λ×V²)/(2g×D), where ΔH - pressure loss (m), L - length (m), λ - friction coefficient, V - speed (m/s), g - gravitational acceleration (9.81 m/s²), D - diameter (m).

faqItems.q: What factors influence the choice of pipeline diameter?
faqItems.a: The choice of diameter is influenced by: required water flow, permissible flow speed (1.5-2.5 m/s), permissible pressure loss (0.2-0.3 bar per 100 m), pipe material, pipeline length, number of water points, peak flow, presence of a pump and its characteristics.

faqItems.q: How to check the correctness of the calculation of the diameter of the water pipe?
faqItems.a: The correctness of the calculation is checked: the flow speed must be in the range of 1.5-2.5 m/s, the pressure loss must not exceed 0.2-0.3 bar per 100 m, the Reynolds number must correspond to the flow regime, the diameter must be from the standard range, the flow rate must correspond to the required one.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the diameter of a pipe for a fire extinguishing system?
faqItems.a: For a fire extinguishing system, the diameter is calculated based on the required water flow to extinguish the fire (usually 5-10 l/s per point) and the number of points simultaneously. Use pipes with a diameter of 65-150 mm for the main line and 50-80 mm for branches. It is important to ensure sufficient pressure.

faqItems.q: What formulas are used to calculate the diameter of a water pipe?
faqItems.a: The basic formula for calculating the diameter: D = √(4Q/πV), where Q is the flow rate (m³/s), V is the speed (m/s). To check, use the flow formula: Q = πD²V/4. For pressure loss: ΔP = λ×(L/D)×(ρV²/2). Diameter is rounded to the nearest standard value.

overview.title: Crushed stone calculator online
overview.content: The online crushed stone calculator will help you calculate the required amount of crushed stone for various construction works: foundations, paths, blind areas and bedding. The dimensions of the area, the thickness of the layer, the fraction and density of crushed stone, as well as the supply of material are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The crushed stone calculator uses precise formulas to calculate the volume and weight of the material, taking into account the type of work and the characteristics of the crushed stone. Suitable for calculating various fractions: from small (5-10 mm) for decoration to large (40-70 mm) for bedding. Calculation formula: Volume = Area × Thickness or Volume (if specified directly). Weight = Volume × Density. Taking into account the stock: Final volume = Volume × (1 + Stock / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Examples of crushed stone calculations
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the amount of crushed stone for various types of work:

example1.title: Example 1: Foundation cushion 8x10 m
example1.description: Standard cushion for strip foundation, crushed stone fraction 20-40 mm
example1.input:
Length: 8 m, Width: 10 m, Thickness: 0.2 m
Fraction: 20-40 mm
Density: 1400 kg/m³
Stock: 10%
example1.calculation:
Area: 8 × 10 = 80 m²
Volume: 80 × 0.2 = 16 m³
Weight: 16 × 1400 = 22,400 kg
With reserve: 16 × 1.1 = 17.6 m³
Weight with reserve: 17.6 × 1400 = 24.640 kg
example1.note: For the foundation, a fraction of 20-40 mm is recommended for better compaction

example2.title: Example 2: Garden path 15x1 m
example2.description: Garden path made of crushed stone, fraction 10-20 mm
example2.input:
Length: 15 m, Width: 1 m, Thickness: 0.1 m
Fraction: 10-20 mm
Density: 1450 kg/m³
Stock: 15%
example2.calculation:
Area: 15 × 1 = 15 m²
Volume: 15 × 0.1 = 1.5 m³
Weight: 1.5 × 1450 = 2.175 kg
With a margin: 1.5 × 1.15 = 1.725 m³
Weight with reserve: 1.725 × 1450 = 2.501 kg
example2.note: For paths, a finer grain size is recommended for ease of walking.

example3.title: Example 3: Blind area around the house
example3.description: Blind area 1 m wide around the house 10×12 m, crushed stone 20-40 mm
example3.input:
Perimeter: 44 m, Width: 1 m, Thickness: 0.15 m
Fraction: 20-40 mm
Density: 1400 kg/m³
Stock: 10%
example3.calculation:
Area: 44 × 1 = 44 m²
Volume: 44 × 0.15 = 6.6 m³
Weight: 6.6 × 1400 = 9,240 kg
With reserve: 6.6 × 1.1 = 7.26 m³
Weight with reserve: 7.26 × 1400 = 10.164 kg
example3.note: The blind area protects the foundation from water; the correct thickness is important

example4.title: Example 4: Backfill for tiles 20×15 m
example4.description: Leveling bedding for paving slabs, coarse fraction
example4.input:
Area: 300 m², Thickness: 0.08 m
Fraction: 20-40 mm
Density: 1400 kg/m³
Stock: 5%
example4.calculation:
Volume: 300 × 0.08 = 24 m³
Weight: 24 × 1400 = 33,600 kg
With reserve: 24 × 1.05 = 25.2 m³
Weight with reserve: 25.2 × 1400 = 35.280 kg
example4.note: For backfilling under tiles, uniform layer thickness is important.

example5.title: Example 5: Decorative path with small crushed stone
example5.description: Decorative path made of fine crushed stone 5-10 mm
example5.input:
Length: 10 m, Width: 0.8 m, Thickness: 0.05 m
Fraction: 5-10 mm
Density: 1500 kg/m³
Stock: 20%
example5.calculation:
Area: 10 × 0.8 = 8 m²
Volume: 8 × 0.05 = 0.4 m³
Weight: 0.4 × 1500 = 600 kg
With a margin: 0.4 × 1.2 = 0.48 m³
Weight with reserve: 0.48 × 1500 = 720 kg
example5.note: Small crushed stone is used for decorative purposes

example6.title: Example 6: Large area of ​​bedding
example6.description: Leveling a large area, volume 50 m³
example6.input:
Volume: 50 m³
Fraction: 40-70 mm
Density: 1350 kg/m³
Stock: 10%
example6.calculation:
Weight: 50 × 1350 = 67,500 kg
With reserve: 50 × 1.1 = 55 m³
Weight with reserve: 55 × 1350 = 74.250 kg
example6.note: For large volumes, it is more profitable to order crushed stone in tons with delivery

faq.title: Frequently asked questions about calculating crushed stone

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of crushed stone for the foundation?
faqItems.a: For a pillow under the foundation, calculate the area of ​​the foundation and multiply by the thickness of the layer (usually 0.15-0.2 m). Example: foundation 8x10 m, thickness 0.2 m → area 80 m², volume 16 m³. With a margin of 10%: 17.6 m³ of crushed stone.

faqItems.q: What fraction of crushed stone is needed for the foundation?
faqItems.a: For the foundation cushion, crushed stone of a fraction of 20-40 mm is usually used. This fraction compacts well and provides a reliable base. For concrete in the foundation, a fraction of 5-20 mm or 20-40 mm is used.

faqItems.q: How much crushed stone is needed for a path?
faqItems.a: For a garden path, calculate the area (length × width) and multiply by the layer thickness (usually 0.1-0.15 m). Example: track 15×1 m, thickness 0.1 m → area 15 m², volume 1.5 m³. With a margin of 15%: 1.725 m³ of crushed stone.

faqItems.q: What crushed stone density is used for calculations?
faqItems.a: The density of crushed stone depends on the fraction and rock: granite crushed stone 5-10 mm - 1500 kg/m³, 10-20 mm - 1450 kg/m³, 20-40 mm - 1400 kg/m³, 40-70 mm - 1350 kg/m³. Limestone crushed stone is usually 100-200 kg/m³ lighter.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the volume of crushed stone for a blind area?
faqItems.a: The blind area is calculated around the perimeter of the house. Example: house 10×12 m, perimeter 44 m, width of the blind area 1 m, thickness 0.15 m → area 44 m², volume 6.6 m³. With a margin of 10%: 7.26 m³ of crushed stone.

faqItems.q: Do I need a supply of crushed stone when purchasing?
faqItems.a: Yes, always add a reserve of 10-15% crushed stone. The reserve takes into account shrinkage during compaction, unevenness of the site and possible losses during transportation and installation.

faqItems.q: How to convert the weight of crushed stone into volume?
faqItems.a: Volume = Weight / Density. For example, 14,000 kg of crushed stone with a density of 1,400 kg/m³ = 14,000 / 1,400 = 10 m³. For reverse calculation: Weight = Volume × Density.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to use different fractions of crushed stone?
faqItems.a: Yes, different fractions are used for different jobs: 5-10 mm - decorative paths, 10-20 mm - standard paths and foundation, 20-40 mm - foundation cushion and blind area, 40-70 mm - backfill and leveling.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the amount of crushed stone for backfilling under tiles?
faqItems.a: To backfill under paving slabs, calculate the area and multiply by the thickness of the layer (usually 0.05-0.1 m). Example: area 300 m², thickness 0.08 m → volume 24 m³. With a margin of 5%: 25.2 m³ of crushed stone.

faqItems.q: How much does 1 m³ of crushed stone weigh?
faqItems.a: The weight of 1 m³ of crushed stone depends on the fraction and rock: granite 5-10 mm - 1500 kg, 10-20 mm - 1450 kg, 20-40 mm - 1400 kg, 40-70 mm - 1350 kg. Limestone crushed stone is usually 100-200 kg lighter than granite.

faqItems.q: How to calculate crushed stone for a large area?
faqItems.a: For a large area, measure the area or enter the volume directly. If the area is large, divide it into sections and calculate separately. Don't forget to add a margin of 10-15% for shrinkage.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to mix different fractions of crushed stone?
faqItems.a: Yes, sometimes different fractions are mixed for better compaction. For example, for a foundation cushion they can use a mixture of 20-40 mm and 40-70 mm in a 70/30 ratio. The calculator allows you to specify the average density of the mixture.

faqItems.q: How to take into account the shrinkage of crushed stone when compacting?
faqItems.a: Shrinkage of crushed stone during compaction is usually 10-15%. This is taken into account in the material stock. If the reserve is not specified separately, it is recommended to add 10-15% to the calculated volume.

faqItems.q: What is the thickness of the crushed stone layer for the foundation?
faqItems.a: The thickness of the foundation cushion is usually 0.15-0.2 m for a strip foundation and 0.2-0.3 m for a slab foundation. For concrete preparation under the foundation, the layer of crushed stone can be 0.1-0.15 m.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the perimeter for a blind area?
faqItems.a: Perimeter of the house for the blind area = 2 × (Length + Width). Example: house 10 × 12 m → perimeter = 2 × (10 + 12) = 44 m. Blind area = Perimeter × Blind area width.

faqItems.q: How much crushed stone is needed per 1 m² of path?
faqItems.a: Depends on the thickness of the layer. With a thickness of 0.1 m: 1 m² × 0.1 m = 0.1 m³. With a density of 1450 kg/m³, this is 145 kg of crushed stone. With a thickness of 0.15 m: 0.15 m³ or 217.5 kg per 1 m².

faqItems.q: How to choose a fraction of crushed stone for a path?
faqItems.a: For garden paths, a fraction of 10-20 mm or 20-40 mm is recommended. The fine fraction is more comfortable for walking, the coarse fraction allows water to pass through better. For decorative paths you can use 5-10 mm.

faqItems.q: How to calculate crushed stone for leveling a site?
faqItems.a: To level, measure the area of ​​the site and the average depth of holes or differences in height. Volume = Area × Average thickness. Add a margin of 10-15% for shrinkage during compaction.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to use sand instead of crushed stone for a pillow?
faqItems.a: It is recommended to use crushed stone for the foundation cushion, as it drains water better and does not shrink. Sand can be used as an additional layer on top of crushed stone.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of crushed stone?
faqItems.a: Cost = Volume × Price per m³ or Weight × Price per ton. Example: 17.6 m³ of crushed stone for 1500 ₽/m³ = 26,400 ₽. Or 24,640 kg (24.64 t) at 2000 ₽/t = 49,280 ₽.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between crushed stone and gravel?
faqItems.a: Crushed stone is obtained by crushing rocks; it has sharp edges. Gravel is a natural material with rounded grains. Crushed stone is usually used for construction, and gravel for decoration. Density and calculation are similar.

faqItems.q: How to transport crushed stone?
faqItems.a: Crushed stone is transported by dump trucks, measuring volume in m³ or weight in tons. A standard dump truck transports 10-20 m³ of crushed stone. When ordering, please indicate the volume or weight for the correct selection of transport.

faqItems.q: Is it necessary to compact crushed stone when laying it?
faqItems.a: Yes, crushed stone must be compacted (tamped) after laying. When compacting, shrinkage occurs by 10-15%, which must be taken into account when calculating. The compaction ensures the strength and stability of the base.

faqItems.q: How to calculate crushed stone for drainage?
faqItems.a: For drainage, large crushed stone of a fraction of 20-40 mm or 40-70 mm is used. Calculate the volume of the trench: length × width × depth. Example: trench 50×0.5×0.5 m = 12.5 m³. With a margin of 10%: 13.75 m³.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to use recycled crushed stone?
faqItems.a: Recycled crushed stone (from crushed concrete) can be used for bedding and paths, but not for a foundation cushion. The density of secondary crushed stone is slightly lower, about 1200-1300 kg/m³.

faqItems.q: How to calculate crushed stone for parking?
faqItems.a: For parking, calculate the area and multiply by the thickness of the layer (usually 0.2-0.25 m). Example: parking 20×10 m, thickness 0.2 m → area 200 m², volume 40 m³. With a margin of 10%: 44 m³ of crushed stone.

faqItems.q: What is the thickness of the crushed stone blind area?
faqItems.a: The thickness of a crushed stone blind area is usually 0.1-0.2 m. For reliable protection of the foundation, a thickness of 0.15-0.2 m is recommended. The width of the blind area should be at least 0.6-0.8 m.

faqItems.q: How to take into account the slope angle when calculating?
faqItems.a: For sloped areas, calculate the average layer thickness. If the slope is significant, divide the site into parts and calculate each separately. The slope of the blind area is usually 2-5% of the foundation.

faqItems.q: How much crushed stone do you need to put under a fence?
faqItems.a: To backfill under a fence, calculate the length of the fence, the width of the backfill and the thickness of the layer. Example: fence 50 m, bedding width 0.5 m, thickness 0.1 m → area 25 m², volume 2.5 m³. With a margin of 10%: 2.75 m³.

faqItems.q: How to calculate crushed stone for concrete?
faqItems.a: For concrete, crushed stone is included in the mixture. Typically the proportion is 1:3:5 (cement:sand:crushed stone). To calculate crushed stone in concrete, use a concrete calculator, which takes into account all components of the mixture.

faqItems.q: Can the calculator be used for different types of crushed stone?
faqItems.a: Yes, the calculator works with any type of crushed stone (granite, limestone, gravel). The only difference is the density, which can be specified manually. Granite crushed stone is denser than limestone.

step1.text: Specify the type of work: foundation, path, blind area or bedding

step5.text: Specify the percentage of material reserve (usually 10-15%) to compensate for shrinkage during compaction

seo.title: Online electrical calculator - Calculation of cable cross-sections and machines | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online electrical calculator for accurate calculation of cable cross-section and power of circuit breakers. Takes into account load power, cable length, conductor material, voltage drop.
seo.keywords: electrical calculator, cable cross-section calculation, machine calculation, wire cross-section calculator, machine rating, cable selection, cable cross-section by power, cable cross-section by current, circuit breaker, machine power calculation, machine selection, voltage drop, copper cable, aluminum cable, single-phase network, three-phase network, electrical wiring, online electrical calculator, electrical wiring calculation, wire cross-section for sockets, wire cross-section for lighting, circuit breaker rating for home, choice of cable for wiring, electrical calculator

overview.title: Online electrical calculator
overview.content: An online electrical calculator will help you calculate the required cable cross-section and the rating of the circuit breaker for electrical wiring. Load power, current, voltage, cable length, conductor material (copper or aluminum), network type (single-phase or three-phase) and permissible voltage drop are taken into account.
overview.additionalContent: The electrical calculator uses exact formulas and standards of the PUE (Electrical Installation Rules) to calculate the cable cross-section and select the machine. Suitable for calculating electrical wiring in apartments, houses, offices and industrial premises. Formulas: Cable Section = I × √(L × ΔU) / (k × U) or Section = I / J, where I - current, L - length, ΔU - voltage drop, k - material coefficient, U - voltage, J - current density. Machine denomination = I × 1.25 (with a margin of 25%).

calculationExamples.title: Electrical calculation examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the cable cross-section and power of the machines for various types of loads:

example1.title: Example 1: Sockets in an apartment
example1.description: Group of sockets in the apartment, power 2.5 kW
example1.input:
Power: 2.5 kW
Voltage: 220 V
Cable length: 15 m
Material: Copper
Network type: Single phase
Voltage drop: 3%
example1.calculation:
Current: 2500 / (220 × 0.9) = 12.6 A
Current Density (Copper): 4 A/mm²
Current cross-section: 12.6 / 4 = 3.15 mm²
Standard cross-section: 2.5 mm² is not enough, choose 4 mm²
Machine rating: 12.6 × 1.25 = 15.75 A → 16 A (type C)
Voltage drop: 0.8%
example1.result: Cable cross-section: 4 mm² (copper), Automatic: 16 A (type C)
example1.note: For sockets, a copper cable with a cross-section of at least 2.5 mm² is recommended, but for a length of more than 10 m it is better to use 4 mm²

example2.title: Example 2: Lighting in the house
example2.description: Lighting group, power 0.5 kW
example2.input:
Power: 0.5 kW
Voltage: 220 V
Cable length: 25 m
Material: Copper
Network type: Single phase
Voltage drop: 3%
example2.calculation:
Current: 500 / (220 × 0.95) = 2.4 A
Current Density (Copper): 4 A/mm²
Current cross-section: 2.4 / 4 = 0.6 mm²
Standard cross-section: 1.5 mm²
Machine rating: 2.4 × 1.25 = 3 A → 6 A (type C)
Voltage drop: 0.5%
example2.result: Cable cross-section: 1.5 mm² (copper), Automatic: 6 A (type C)
example2.note: For lighting, a 1.5 mm² copper cable and a 6-10 A circuit breaker are sufficient.

example3.title: Example 3: Electric stove
example3.description: Electric stove with a power of 7.5 kW
example3.input:
Power: 7.5 kW
Voltage: 220 V
Cable length: 8m
Material: Copper
Network type: Single phase
Voltage drop: 3%
example3.calculation:
Current: 7500 / (220 × 0.9) = 37.9 A
Current Density (Copper): 4 A/mm²
Current cross-section: 37.9 / 4 = 9.5 mm²
Standard cross-section: 10 mm²
Machine rating: 37.9 × 1.25 = 47.4 A → 50 A (type C)
Voltage drop: 1.2%
example3.result: Cable cross-section: 10 mm² (copper), Automatic: 50 A (type C)
example3.note: Powerful consumers require a large cross-section cable and a corresponding circuit breaker.

example4.title: Example 4: Three-phase motor
example4.description: Three-phase asynchronous motor 5.5 kW
example4.input:
Power: 5.5 kW
Voltage: 380V
Cable length: 30 m
Material: Copper
Network type: Three-phase
Voltage drop: 3%
example4.calculation:
Current: 5500 / (√3 × 380 × 0.85) = 9.8 A
Current Density (Copper): 4 A/mm²
Current cross-section: 9.8 / 4 = 2.45 mm²
Standard cross-section: 2.5 mm²
Machine rating: 9.8 × 1.25 = 12.25 A → 16 A (type D)
Voltage drop: 2.1%
example4.result: Cable cross-section: 2.5 mm² (copper), Automatic: 16 A (type D)
example4.note: For motors, type D circuit breaker is used for protection against inrush currents

example5.title: Example 5: Aluminum cable for home
example5.description: Input cable to a private house, power 10 kW
example5.input:
Power: 10 kW
Voltage: 220 V
Cable length: 50 m
Material: Aluminum
Network type: Single phase
Voltage drop: 3%
example5.calculation:
Current: 10000 / (220 × 0.9) = 50.5 A
Current density (aluminum): 3 A/mm²
Current cross-section: 50.5 / 3 = 16.8 mm²
Standard cross-section: 16 mm²
Machine rating: 50.5 × 1.25 = 63.1 A → 63 A (type C)
Voltage drop: 2.8%
example5.result: Cable cross-section: 16 mm² (aluminum), Automatic: 63 A (type C)
example5.note: Aluminum cable requires a larger cross-section, but is cheaper than copper

example6.title: Example 6: Outdoor lighting
example6.description: Street lighting, power 1 kW, long line
example6.input:
Power: 1 kW
Voltage: 220 V
Cable length: 100 m
Material: Copper
Network type: Single phase
Voltage drop: 3%
example6.calculation:
Current: 1000 / (220 × 0.95) = 4.8 A
Current Density (Copper): 4 A/mm²
Current cross-section: 4.8 / 4 = 1.2 mm²
Voltage drop cross-section: 4 mm² required
Standard cross-section: 4 mm²
Machine rating: 4.8 × 1.25 = 6 A → 10 A (type C)
Voltage drop: 2.9%
example6.result: Cable cross-section: 4 mm² (copper), Automatic: 10 A (type C)
example6.note: With long lines, the deciding factor is the voltage drop rather than the current density

calculation.title: How to calculate cable cross-section and machine power
calculation.content: The electrical calculation includes several stages to obtain an accurate result, taking into account all load parameters and installation conditions.
calculation.current: Load current = Power / (Voltage × cos φ) for single-phase network, Current = Power / (√3 × Voltage × cos φ) for three-phase
calculation.cableSection: Cable Section = Current / Current Density or Section = (2 × ρ × L × I) / (ΔU × U), where ρ is resistivity, L is length, I is current, ΔU is voltage drop, U is voltage
calculation.breaker: Machine rating = Current × 1.25 (25% margin) or Rating = Current × Machine type coefficient
calculation.voltageDrop: Voltage drop = (2 × ρ × L × I) / (S × U) × 100%, where S is the cable cross-section

steps.current: Calculation of load current by power and voltage
steps.section: Determination of cable cross-section by current and voltage drop
steps.breaker: Selecting the machine's nominal value with a margin of 25%

advantages.title: Benefits of an electrical calculator
advantages.content: Using an electrical calculator provides many advantages when designing electrical wiring: accurate calculation of cable cross-section, correct choice of machine, safety, saving on materials.
advantages.safety: Ensuring the safety of electrical wiring

tips.title: Tips for electrical calculations
tips.content: To get an accurate result, follow our recommendations when calculating electrical wiring.
tips.measurement: Carefully measure the cable length with a margin of 10%
tips.material: Choose copper for new wiring, aluminum only for budget options
tips.reserve: Always choose a machine with a margin of 25% of the rated current
tips.voltageDrop: Monitor the voltage drop, no more than 3-5%

faq.title: Frequently asked questions about electrical calculations

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for sockets?
faqItems.a: For sockets, calculate the load current: I = P / (U × cos φ). Select the current cross-section: for copper, the current density is 4 A/mm², for aluminum 3 A/mm². Example: power 2.5 kW, current 12.6 A → cross-section 4 mm² (copper) or 6 mm² (aluminium).

faqItems.q: What rating of the machine is needed for sockets?
faqItems.a: Machine rating = Design current × 1.25 (25% margin). For sockets, 16 A or 25 A (type C) circuit breakers are usually used. Example: current 12.6 A → automatic 16 A (12.6 × 1.25 = 15.75 A).

faqItems.q: What cable cross-section is needed for lighting?
faqItems.a: For lighting, a copper cable with a cross section of 1.5 mm² and a 6-10 A circuit breaker are usually sufficient. For line lengths of more than 30 m, it is better to use 2.5 mm² to compensate for the voltage drop.

faqItems.q: What is the difference between copper and aluminum cable?
faqItems.a: Copper: current density 4 A/mm², conducts current better, more expensive, but more reliable. Aluminum: current density 3 A/mm², cheaper, but requires a larger cross-section and is less reliable in connections. Copper is recommended for new wiring.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for an electric stove?
faqItems.a: For a 7.5 kW stove: current = 7500 / (220 × 0.9) = 37.9 A. Copper cross-section: 37.9 / 4 = 9.5 mm² → choose 10 mm². Automatic: 37.9 × 1.25 = 47.4 A → 50 A (type C).

faqItems.q: Which type of machine should I choose: B, C or D?
faqItems.a: Type B: for slightly inductive loads (lamps, heaters). Type C: for household loads (sockets, lighting) - the most common. Type D: for high starting currents (motors, compressors).

faqItems.q: How to take into account voltage drop when calculating?
faqItems.a: The voltage drop should not exceed 3-5%. For long lines (>30 m), choose a larger cable cross-section. Formula: ΔU = (2 × ρ × L × I) / (S × U) × 100%, where ρ is resistivity (0.0175 for copper), L is length, I is current, S is cross-section, U is voltage.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for a three-phase network?
faqItems.a: For a three-phase network, the current is calculated: I = P / (√3 × U × cos φ), where √3 ≈ 1.73. Then the cross section is selected according to the current density: for copper 4 A/mm², for aluminum 3 A/mm². Example: 5.5 kW, 380 V → current 9.8 A → cross-section 2.5 mm² (copper).

faqItems.q: Is it necessary to increase the cable cross-section for hidden installation?
faqItems.a: Yes, with hidden installation the permissible current density is lower due to worse heat dissipation. For copper in a hidden gasket: 3 A/mm² instead of 4 A/mm². For aluminum: 2 A/mm² instead of 3 A/mm².

faqItems.q: How to calculate the rating of a machine for a group of sockets?
faqItems.a: Calculate the total power of all sockets in the group, then the current: I = P / (U × cos φ). Machine denomination = I × 1.25. Example: 5 sockets of 2 kW = 10 kW, current 45.5 A → automatic 50 A or 63 A (type C).

faqItems.q: Is it possible to use one machine for several groups?
faqItems.a: Yes, but each group must have a separate circuit breaker in the distribution board. The input machine is calculated for the total load of all groups with a simultaneity coefficient of 0.7-0.8.

faqItems.q: How to choose the cable cross-section for entry into the house?
faqItems.a: The input cable is calculated for the total power of all consumers with a simultaneity coefficient of 0.7-0.8. Example: house 10 kW, coefficient 0.8 = 8 kW, current 36.4 A → cable 10 mm² (copper) or 16 mm² (aluminum).

faqItems.q: What is power factor (cos φ)?
faqItems.a: Power factor shows the ratio of active power to apparent power. For household loads cos φ = 0.8-0.9 (lamps, heaters), for engines cos φ = 0.7-0.85. At low cos φ, more current is required for the same power.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for a motor?
faqItems.a: For a motor: current = Power / (√3 × U × cos φ × η), where η is efficiency (usually 0.85-0.9). Then the cross section: for copper 4 A/mm², for aluminum 3 A/mm². The machine is selected as type D with a margin of 1.5-2 from the rated current for protection against inrush currents.

faqItems.q: What voltage drop is acceptable?
faqItems.a: According to the PUE, the voltage drop in the section from the source to the consumer should not exceed 5% for lighting networks and 3% for power networks. In practice, they try not to exceed 3% for all networks.

faqItems.q: How to calculate cable resistance?
faqItems.a: Cable resistance: R = (ρ × L) / S, where ρ is the resistivity (0.0175 Ohm mm²/m for copper, 0.0283 for aluminum), L is the length in meters, S is the cross-section in mm². Voltage drop: ΔU = 2 × R × I for a single-phase network, ΔU = √3 × R × I for a three-phase network.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to use aluminum cable in an apartment?
faqItems.a: According to PUE 7.1.34, in residential buildings with a cross-section of less than 16 mm², only copper cable should be used. Aluminum cable can only be used with a cross-section of 16 mm² and above, but copper is recommended for new wiring.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for several consumers?
faqItems.a: Calculate the total power of all consumers taking into account the simultaneity factor (usually 0.7-0.8). Then the current and cable cross-section. Example: consumers 8+5+3 kW, coefficient 0.8 = 12.8 kW, current 58 A → cable 16 mm² (copper).

faqItems.q: How much reserve is needed when choosing a machine?
faqItems.a: The machine is selected with a margin of 25% of the calculated current: Rating = I × 1.25. This provides overload protection and prevents false alarms. For motors, the margin may be greater (1.5-2 times) due to starting currents.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section using the table?
faqItems.a: Use PUE tables with permissible currents for various sections and laying methods. For copper open installation: 1.5 mm² - 19 A, 2.5 mm² - 27 A, 4 mm² - 38 A, 6 mm² - 50 A. For hidden installation, the currents are 20-30% lower.

faqItems.q: What to do if the voltage drop exceeds the norm?
faqItems.a: Increase the cable cross-section. The voltage drop is inversely proportional to the cross-section: when the cross-section increases by 2 times, the drop decreases by 2 times. It is also possible to reduce the line length or use a higher voltage (380 V instead of 220 V).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for low-voltage lighting (12 V)?
faqItems.a: For low-voltage lighting, the current is much higher: I = P / U. At a voltage of 12 V for a power of 100 W, current = 100 / 12 = 8.3 A. A larger cable cross-section is required: 2.5-4 mm² to compensate for the high current and voltage drop.

faqItems.q: Can one cable be used for multiple groups?
faqItems.a: Yes, you can use one cable to the junction box, then separate it into groups. The cross-section of the main cable is calculated for the total load of all groups with a simultaneity factor of 0.7-0.8.

faqItems.q: How to take into account the ambient temperature?
faqItems.a: At temperatures above 25°C the permissible current density decreases. At 35°C: for copper 3.5 A/mm², at 40°C: 3 A/mm². At temperatures below 25°C, the current density can be increased, but not by more than 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for grounding?
faqItems.a: The grounding conductor must have a cross-section of at least: for phase up to 16 mm² - equal to phase, for phase 16-35 mm² - 16 mm², for phase over 35 mm² - half of phase, but not less than 16 mm².

faqItems.q: What kind of machine is needed for an electric motor?
faqItems.a: For the motor, an automatic type D with a rating of 1.5-2.5 of the rated current of the motor is selected for protection against inrush currents. Example: motor 5.5 kW, current 11 A → automatic 16-25 A (type D). A thermal relay with a setting of 1.05-1.2 of the rated current is also used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for a heating system?
faqItems.a: Electric heating has high power. Example: 3 kW heater, current 13.6 A → 4 mm² cable (copper), 16 A automatic (type C). For several heaters, calculate the total power with the simultaneity factor.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to use a cable with a smaller cross-section than rated?
faqItems.a: No, using a cable with a smaller cross-section is dangerous: overheating, fire, loss of power due to voltage drop. Always choose a standard section equal to or larger than the design one. You can take a larger section for reserve.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for a bath or sauna?
faqItems.a: For a bath, consider high temperature and humidity. Use a double-insulated cable (VVGng-LS) and select a cross-section with a margin of 20-30%. Automatic device with RCD for protection against electric shock. Example: 6 kW, current 27 A → cable 6 mm² (copper), automatic 32 A + RCD.

faqItems.q: What are standard cable sizes?
faqItems.a: Standard copper cable cross-sections: 0.75, 1, 1.5, 2.5, 4, 6, 10, 16, 25, 35, 50, 70, 95, 120, 150, 185, 240, 300, 400, 500 mm². The nearest larger standard section to the calculated one is selected.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cable cross-section for an air conditioner?
faqItems.a: The air conditioner has high starting power. Example: air conditioner 2.5 kW, current 11.4 A, but taking into account the starting current up to 25 A → cable 4 mm² (copper), automatic 16 A (type C) or 20 A for reliability.

faqItems.q: How to take cable length into account when calculating?
faqItems.a: For cable lengths up to 30 m, the voltage drop is usually not critical. For lengths of 30-50 m, take into account the voltage drop when choosing a cross-section. For lengths greater than 50 m, be sure to calculate the voltage drop and select a larger cross-section.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to use a calculator to calculate power networks?
faqItems.a: Yes, the calculator is suitable for calculating power networks (380 V, three-phase). The current is calculated using the formula for a three-phase network, the cross-section is selected taking into account the voltage drop. For industrial networks, installation coefficients and environmental conditions are additionally taken into account.
